Lucky Star is complete trash. And so am I.
This anime has no real story. No development. No drama. No real story. No fan-service. No stand-out features. No real story. And yet somehow this anime completely won me over.
As I said before, Lucky Star doesn't have a real story. If anything, I would describe it as a "character driven narrative" or something along those lines. It follows the everyday lives of a group of high school girls doing what high school girls do, like debating on how to eat food, making Haruhi references, and spending every chance you can playing MMO's with your teacher and copyinghomework off of your conveniently smart friend. Yes, Lucky Star might not be anything like how real Japanese school girls act, but it's the unusual conversations that these girls have that make it so bloody entertaining.


Oh, did I mention this is a parody? I probably should have, because that's one of the main appeals of this show. I don't think you can truly appreciate Lucky Star unless you've watched a fair amount of anime. Seriously, I swear there's got to be at least 10 references in each episode. It's both hilarious and annoying. Hilarious if you get the reference. Annoying if you don't.


I said at the begin that this would be considered a "character driven narrative" in my perspective. Well, what I meant by that was that the characters are literally the entire show. From the mega-otaku, Konata, to the genius airhead, Miyuki, there's definitely a loli or two in here to suit everyone's taste.


One final thing I wanted to mention was Lucky Channel. At the end of every episode, there's a fourth wall breaking additional show segment featuring Kogami Akira and her loyal assistant, Shiraishi Minoru. I won't spoil anything, but the way that LC builds up over time is pure genius and makes me laugh every time. Definitely one of the highlights of the show.


All in all, Lucky Star is a fantastic anime with a loveable cast of colourful characters and some of the funniest moments in all of anime. It's definitely worth a watch if you're into the slice of life genre or if you're just looking for a good time.


Hope that helped.

Wow well this is a tough one. You know this is one of those animes which either you hate it or you love it.
When I started watching this anime I was new to the whole anime fiasco. I had not seen The melancholy of Haruhi Suzumia (a must see before this anime) or actually a lot of the animes that are referred in the show which in the end make me think that this is a boring slice of life anime with no comedy, no character development and with bad art style (boy was I wrong).
A year after my initial view of the show (Idropped it on episode 5 or 6 i think) I said to myself that I will watch it to the end and that every anime at least deserves to be re seen a second time to analyses what actually is bad in it. So I watched the first 12 episodes and I found myself unable to stop laughing so I continued to watch it and actually finished the anime in one sitting. It was that good now. I now started to see the humor in this anime was - the characters that I said were shabby and non developed suddenly started to be funny and interesting. Each and every character was likable and the best part is that I started to make connections with my friends and the character from the anime (and I think that this is a really big + to a slice of life anime).


Well it is absolutely hard to recommend this anime because like I said this anime will most certainly not appeal to everyone's taste but it has potential. The music is good in the anime, especially the bloody opening... I still have it stuck in my head and it has been a long time since I saw this anime for the last time.

The story is lacking a little bit because there isn`t an actual story right up to the end, but that is it`s charm that it takes everything lightly including it`s story.


The art well let`s face it, it isn`t that good (my first reaction was THIS IS HORRIBLE to be honest with you), but again it gives the anime it`s personality.


The characters are lovable ( heck because of the main character I now write smiles like this :3 because they remind me of how funny she was). Well the anime tries to develop some specific and actually stereotypical character traits seen in the slice of life genre. For example we have the tsundere, the moe, the airhead and of course the die hard comedian type character (oh my sweet sweet Konata.)


To wrap this up. The anime is a parody/slice of life anime. It has it`s ups and downs. You need to watch a few other animes before this one like "The melancholy of Haruhi Suzumia" so that you can understand how brilliant  the humor in this anime is. I will recommend this anime, but be warned that I don't guaranty a 100% satisfaction from the first time you watch it.


I will paraphrase a funny line that the dubbed Naruto says a lot and is actually relevant for this anime.


Believe in it :3

Four friends in a high school hang out with each other and chat about things with their other girlfriends. Most notable among them is Konata Izumi, a video game / anime fanatic who's actually pretty smart and athletic, but doesn't like sports or putting effort into her schoolwork. Her other friends include twin sisters Kagami and Tsukasa and the pretty, smart, but also clumsy Miyuki.
And then there's Lucky Channel. Shown at the end of every episode before the ending theme, it's a mini-segment that stars washed-up idol Akira Kogami and her assistant, Minoru Shirashi, voiced and modeled after his actor. Their main goal is totalk about the series, including its cast, at first, but eventually it turns into a look into Akira's unhappy career and her wanting to be in the main series, as well as focusing on her less-than-stellar relationship with Minoru. Unlike the rest of the series, the Lucky Channel segment does have a (loose) plot of sorts, so if you plan to skim around the series, make sure you avoid these segments lest you get confused. That's not a spoiler, right? God I suck at these reviews. that's right i said i suck at it thus compliment me on how great I am at life. No one cares? Well let's get on with the review.


Konata Izumi, the main protagonist, has a fetish for chocolate cornets, as well as a number of anime and manga shows that are also popular. Not surprisingly, she is an avid follower of Haruhi Suzumiya (the seiyuu of both characters is Aya Hirano), and you also have plenty of other anime and manga references. And in spite all her bubblyness, and the catlike smile she loves to sport, she has skeletons in the closet, too: her mother died when she was young. She is a "Jill of all trades," the renaissance girl, and the otaku, all in one.


Kagami Hiiragi is the tsundere-type of girl in this series, and a popular girl in her class. Aesthetically, she is an interesting person to pay attention to, more so than her sister Tsukasa, although there are attributes that make her unique. Miyuki Takara is your meganekko in the show, and after Konata talks with her about what her weaknesses are, she sees her in the moekko mold. The supporting characters have their unique quirks: Yui Narumi, Konata's cousin, and her teacher, Nanako Kuroi, are akin to Yukari Tanizaki and Minamo Kurosawa in AzuDai. 


Some other well known characters outside of Lucky Star even cameo in the series, like Sergeant Frog. I feel it may take away from the story, but these guest stars add another dimension to this sitcom of a series. Lucky Star can also be thought of as a sitcom in a way, a situational comedy with punchlines at every twist and turn.


The story plot, which is weak, is strengthened with the characters, who reflect different personalities and persuasions. It's a pretty decent balance.


So we talked about the characters in the series for quite a while. How are the actual jokes in this series, you might wonder? Well, due to the series' long length, there are just as many hits as misses, if not more so the latter. Many of Lucky Star's jokes fall into two realms: everyday Japanese life, and media references. I counted at least three jokes that had to do with Aya Hirano herself.These jokes wouldn't be too bad in small doses, or if they were consistent, but often you have a typical, reference-free episode and then are suddenly hit with a bunch of them. You can still enjoy the series well enough without getting them all, but you'll lose a part of the reason to watch the series if you do. I'm not familiar with the manga, so I'm not sure if they name-drop references as often as the anime, but if they do I doubt it's as hard.


The situational music is perhaps the down side because it isn't even necessary for most scenarios. I personally believe that it doesn't need it. The background music from other series in Lucky Star, such as "Hare Hare Yukai" when Konata plays on a taiko simulator, or Aya Hirano's "God knows..." during a concert that the girls watch, is acceptable, but the original situational music could be best dealt without.


There is good stuff in Lucky Star, but it’s overwhelmed by so much mediocrity. There was a section towards the end of the series where I hadn't laughed for several consecutive episodes, and was ready to write this off as another “overstayed its welcome” comedy, but the last two episodes were among the most entertaining of the series. Everyone is going to react slightly differently to this series, as evidenced by the wide range of responses to it.


So re you an otaku who wants to have a perfect otaku girlfriend? I PRESENT Izumi Konata. But since I'm a NonOtaku I'll just walk away. Alone. Sadlife .

A true slice-of-life anime that warms my heart.  Every episode seems to bring in minute details that pertain to life that most animes overlook.  The entire theme of this series (which to my knowledge seems to be Friendship) remains abundantly clear throughout the entire series and not once is it seen as otherwise.  With no real plot and very little transition, it takes a bit of getting used to if you are not familiar with the style of anime.  But once you've found yourself finding details that you can relate to within the characters, the series is bound to find itsplace in your heart.

"Love it or hate it." If there is any anime where this saying is valid, it is Lucky Star. I've never seen anyone who said: "Lucky Star was ok but nothing special."
As for the story - it is non existent. The characters in Lucky Star go to school, meet up in their free time and talk about random things. A friend of mine called Lucky Star "a show of utterly randomness" - and well .... that sentence just describes it.
The character design is cute but a bit simple. Anyways the art is good and it really fits the show so there is nothing to complain.
With"Motteke! Sailor Fuku" Lucky Star has a catchy opening song with a dance in the opening video which I think tries to copy the success of Hare Hare Yukai - the ending of The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya. As for the BGM there is not much to say. It's nothing special but fits the atmosphere of the anime but nothing you really keep in mind. As for the ending songs KyoAni did something rather unusual for an anime. Every episode has it's own ending song. The first 12 ending songs are songs the 4 main characters sing in a karaoke bar - and it really sounds like high school students who are not good at singing trying to do their best. Especially Konata's (voiced boy Hirano Aya) songs are quite unique but not everyone likes them. As for the other 12 endings, 11 are sung by Shiraishi Minoru and also really unique in their own way, the last one was sung by Hiromi Konno, the VA of Akira and just regarding the singing.\n
As for the voice acting itself, the seiyuus did a great job. Especially Hirano Aya did a great job at voicing Konata and you can see her great talent when she imidiately switches her voice from the Konata voice to her Haruhi voice (the one you hear in the other animes she voiced) and back again. As for the other characters KyoAni took a good mix of well known seiyuus and some less known. Especially Shiraishi Minoru (who voiced himself) and Sasaki Nozomi who voiced Patricia Martin did good jobs.\n\n
When a series doesn't really have a story it needs something other to be successfull. In Lucky Star's case it are imho the characters. Lucky Star has quite a couple of important characters. There are Konata - an overall hardcore female otaku, Kagami who is supposed to be her tsundere counterpart, Tsukasa who is Kagami's a bit air-headed twin sister and Miyuki the rich and smart girl who combines a number of "moe-aspects" such as being a dojikko meganekko who is afraid of dentists.\n
The last few minutes of each episode are filled with the "Lucky Channel" where Kogami Akira (a loli idol) and above mentioned Shiraishi Minoru who is a newbie-voice actor have some kind of talk show.\n
In the later episodes of Lucky Star there are some more characters introduced with Konata's cousin Yutaka at the centre.\n\n
I really enjoyed watching Lucky Star but it took some time to get through to it. Especially the very first episode is hard to watch when you don't know what to expect and the girls talk 8 minutes about how to eat a choco cornet and wether the thin or the fat end is the head of it and why they think it is. After a few episodes KyoAni changed the director of Lucky Star and it's more easy to watch. Lucky Star is full of references to other anime and especially to the Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya - they even overdid it somehow with the Haruhi references - even every character of the SOS Brigade had a little cameo in Lucky Star but on the other hand it's quite obvious why they did it since Haruhi and Lucky Star are both from Kyoto Animation and the main character is voiced by the same seiyuu. Nonetheless watching Lucky Star is much fun, especially when you know a couple of the animes which are parodied.\n\n
Overall Lucky Star is a great slice-of-life commedy anime for experienced watchers since it's a bit difficult to follow an anime with a negliable plot (girls going to school - not more not less) and lots of references to other anime, video games, shampoo advertises and japanese TV shows. I highly recommend to watch a couple of animes before starting with Lucky Star, otherwise you don't understand more than half of the gags told in Lucky Star. Experienced watchers should have much fun with all those references and the way the gags are told. As said in the beginning "Love it or hate it" there is nothing between those two options.

The daily life of 4 high school girls. Sounds boring. Still, I wanted to know what the appeal of Lucky Star was which got it such a high ranking. The art made it look interesting, but it soon gets annoying. I don't like this show, at all, and I blame MAL ratings which made me think this would be a great show.
So basically, this show is about "the daily life of 4 high school girls" and yes exactly that. They just walk around chit-chat/dance/joke trying to make funny shit happen, but it's like "HOW IS THIS SUPPOSED TO BE FUNNY YOU MOTHE-*" The first quotedsentence summarizes the whole show.


This show is supposed to be a comedy. But the comedy sucked, hardcore bish. Hardcore. Most of the comedy is based around Japanese video games and Japanese jokes. Sori I no undrstandi un japanise stufz. Therefore those jokes are worthless, making me do a WTFface. Not once did I laugh from this show. Ok I have to admit... I smiled and sort of laughed when it ended.


The music was alright. Which is the only good thing in this show.


The characters... I've seen pretty much the same personality types in other anime. One's into food,anime,games and will one day become a fatass. One looks prettier than the others with her wig on(It's true I tell you!). One with anger issues, and sucks at chores. And of course! Who could forget, the N3Rd with glasses. -No offence to any real person-


Lucky ☆ Star definitely, does not deserve this high of a ranking.

It is MAL's 15th most-popular Anime. Created by the same people who brought you Haruhi, tt is one of the most watchable animes regardless of age and it's (In this reviewer's own opinion), one of the most loveable animes around today. Lucky Star is an international phenomenon, following the lives of 4 very simple High-School girls as they make their way through High-School. The Anime prides itself on being a slow, laid-back comedy with hints of some fast-paced action dotted at points around the Anime itself. So let's review it shall we??
--STORY--
A big, fairly important part in any form of Media. The story in Lucky-Star,sort-of follows a fairly non-linear progression, and although most episodes themselves do not progress the story any further, there are key moments when you know you are stepping steppings forwards through school. Most School-based Animes will contain really obscure, and skimpily-dressed classmates, however this was not the case. Unless a background character has a specific role or reason to be seen, it will remain a generic bluish-blob, that just mindlessly does stuff. The story-arc is non-existent, with no specific actions from one episode affecting another directly, which shows that this Anime is about...school. It should be said that all events that fill the episode are filled with comedic gold and humour that you can only wish existed in today's TV Shows. It is witty, funny and sometimes, just outrageous. At the end of every episode, there is a 4-minute spot called Lucky Channel which stars 2 other characters ( Akira and  Shiraishi) who simply either talk about the occurences within that day's episode, or more often then not, end up fighting as Akira's true self is a worn-out, angry Idol and Shiraishi, is the 'new flavour', whom Akira feels threatened by. There is also an immensly strong connection between this Anime's older sister, Suzumiya Haruhi no Yuutsu and this becomes immediatly apparent via all of the advertising, and references to the series, including a Cosplay Cafe where Konata works. Following the story was a real treat, and come the final episode, you really do feel relieved, and in a sort-of up-tempo mood, seeing how they ended their final year of school.


The 4 main characters vary greatly between each-other. The twin-sisters Kagami and Tsukasa Higari are both normal girls, but a major difference is, Kagami is a brilliant student although perhaps a little boring, and Tsukasa, not-so, tending to take on the roles of baking, and dreaming big. The Haruhi-rule applies in this anime too, so there is obviously a Moe girl with large-breasts. This gives us Takara Miyuki, a pink-haired beauty, descended from a rich family. The main character is especially interesting, because she embodies all the things an Otaku loves (Like playing Ero-Games to watching Anime and reading Manga) into the body of a short, blue-haired girl named Konata Izumi. This combination of unlikely friends makes a very interesting turn of events, with Konata making obscure references to Animes at all the right times. There are also some other, soon-to-be main characters, but they do not start making appearences until the 2nd half of the series. One character I did like alot was Kusakabe Misou, a hot-headed friend and classmate of Kagami who is just cute, and has an odd sense of humour, bluntly pointing out that Kagami is scary.


--ARTWOOK/ANIMATION--

As a general rule-of-thumb, the artwook is really nice, but then again, feels very plain. There are no overly-drawn, or overly detailed characters or surroundings unlike most Action animes. Being a comedy, it can sort-of get away with this fact, and seeing as how it knows it is not detailed and doens't try too hard, it sort of is acceptable. As stated above, any characters not deemed important to the scene, are just made into Generic blobs which allows you focus much easier on the characters portrayed in the scene and not the background. Throughout a few episodes in the Anime, there stars a very overly-animated Anime-Store Manager and his band of shop-assistants who provide some Action at short intervals (Far and wide between the story) in trying to get Konata to buy stuff from his store. The animation itself, isn't actually that grand (Except for the Anime Store's needlesly volitile staff scenes) and just trys to get by, by only moving mouths, eyes and perhaps hands if need-be. Granted, there are some walking scenes etc. but most of the time, the girls mainly sit around somewhere, talk, or do stuff, and then talk.


--SOUND/MUSIC--

The first thing you should ever note about this series, is the Opening song. Motteke! Sailor Fuku is one of the most popular songs ever to be included on an Anime, reaching almost the same levels of super stardom as the ED theme of this Anime's predessecor. It is a lovely opening staring the main characters singing a Cheerleader's chant about how they want their Summer-Uniform back :) Throughout the Anime, the music-style generally do not change, keeping their slow-styled, almost elevator-like music. Now even this music can vary and they have produced several variences to all of Lucky-Star's songs and they are used fully and well, to create a great atmosphere each and every time. Like the rare action-sequences, there is also a small selection of action-music within the anime, used within these rare scenes. They generally parody some other Anime at this time, so I can't say much for the music-direction here, except that they do fit-in rather well. There is no, one ED song and instead, it is usually just the Main-Characters at a Kareoke Bar, singing a song of some kind. In the 2nd half of the series, the man who plays Shiriashi within Lucky Channel is seen in real-life, usually singing a theme from another Anime.


--ENJOYMENT/OVERALL--

This is, and still remains to be one of my most favorite Animes, and this is proven by the fact that every day, I usually re-watch at least one of the episodes, just because the story is non-linear and allows for you to pick up at any point, and not have to worry about what happened last episode. I also just love Konata's obssessive need to relate everything to an Anime or a Manga title, even when talking about Light-Novels. Basically, to sum up, you just have to watch it, otherwise, your life may go unfulfilled :3

-Aex

I haven't gotten very far into the series yet so you'll have to pardon my incomplete thoughts on the subject
I IMMENSELY enjoyed the first couple episodes while all the girls were in school. The setting was very becoming for the kind of dialogue the series seemed to be going for.. Just not for everyone

Before I say anything, listen all you people planing/considering to watch Lucky Star, this is an anime for people who like random things and can basically laugh at anything even to the people of talking to themselves out loud discussing what they think is going to happen next. If you are a serious person who never laughs or thinks everything has to be perfect this is not the anime for you.
At first I thought it would be one of those boring "high-school-girls-talk-about-guys" show. But after watching the first episode, the first thing that came to my mind was...RANDOM! I find it amazing how they canhave such a random show, and yet make it so awesome! 


I could relate to most of the characters, especially Izumi Konato as I too am an anime fan and have problems laying off it to do homework. It is definatly not your typical slice-of life sort of anime. It is BEYOND ordinary.


I couldn't give it full marks for story because well, there is no story line. Unlike some slice of life animes, this one doesn't have a storyline, but hey think about it, how much story is actually in you life? Go to school/work, play computer games, eat, sleep and if your a good student (which I am not) you would do your homework, not much of a life story is it. But this anime could use that random stuff and yet still make it interesting which I believe it really deserves credit for.


The art. Sure for as seventeen year old, they sure look ten, absolute unrealistic, but this is anime. How realistic are anime characters with pink and blue hair running around shooting laser beams out of their six arms? If you ask me I find the drawing style rather cute. It doesn't matter if they don't look their age, its anime for heavens sake.


The opening isn't exactly the best song I've ever heard in the world, the first four episodes I found it increadibly gay in fact. But later on, it was really catchy and before you know it, it became my ringtone. I am the sort of person with no paitence, I like to skip the openings and endings and only watch the actual content, but I could not bring myself to skip Lucky Stars opening because it was super super catchy. Though I have to admit, I still skip the ending including Lucky Channel.


How are the characters not likeable? I mean, their so random and absolutely human. Full of flaws. Unlike most animes which make you want to be like them because they are so perfect, this one makes you laugh at their flaws and think, I am kinda like that too LOL. Izumi is my favourite cause we both love anime, she is absolutely random and can only think about anime, manga and computer games and only after than can she even be bothered, and if at all, to copy homework. The Lucky Star characters are more human with all their flaws, and make you feel better, people often compare themselves with anime characters and then just laugh it off saying "their is no way i can be as perfect and that." But in Lucky Star you think "Oh, that is just like me, now that I think about it, its time to call Melissa about tomorrows maths homework." I am sure most people that watch this can at least relate to one of the characters if not more.


Enjoyment TEN!!!

Be warned: LS is one of those animes that ppl either absolutely hate it, or absolute love it.  It happens that I LOVE IT; in fact, it is my favourite anime of all time.
It has some pretty standard roster of characters playing stereotypes, but I find them all cute and funny. Great voicing and art on characters too.
Humour depends on you.  To me, it is hilarious and I was bursting in laughter the first time I watch it, but know that it is a slow paced slice of life anime (nothing is gonna happen) and some jokes required further knowledge as they keepalluding to haruhi, otaku culture and other japanese stuff.  Having watched it before I watched Haruhi, I had to go back and rewatch to get some jokes.  Other times it has subtle humour, so ppl with no patience should not watch.  I still remember how it trolled me with the food discussion. wont say anymore.\n\n
It is 100% clean.  If I remember right there is no sexual stuff hinted at all. It manages to make a scene with a bunch of naked characters in spa completely clean.  I like it that way as it has chosen strictly to adhere to its own style of humour.\n\n
tl;dr =  try watching one ep. If you like it then continue. If you dont then stop, cuz its gonna be just like that thruout the whole anime.

Lucky Star is anime that made its debut in 2007 and has generated a fanbase among anime fans new and old alike. While the anime does not offer much in the story category, it does offer the viewer a chance to put the idea of needing a strong story aside and allows us to watch the everyday lives of four highschool girls unfold. 
While this anime may not be for every type of anime fan and that is very understandable, but if you are one of those anime fans who dislike this genre of anime.. is it a bad thing to being risky every nowand then? Being out of your comfort zone might sound like a bad thing, but there are occasions when you just may end up liking a show that you once thought you would not.


Anime like Kiniro Mosaic and A Channel are alright and offers the viewer the same type of experience, but Lucky Star is so incredibly clever that IMO puts this anime on a higher plane than the other two. The obvious best friend relationship that Konata Izumi and Kagami Hiiragi is a perfect example of how clever this anime can get and always seems to put a smile on my face which is something great about anime. Some anime make you sad and others make you scream, but Lucky Star gives you the opposite experience! 


Lucky Star is slowly nearing its seventh birthday and year after year seems to stem more haters, but more fans. A future classic is among us.

Lucky Star is a very fun and creative depiction of the life of high school girls, mainly the characters Konata, Kagami, Tsukasa and Miyuki. It's nothing much but just normal chitchats between these girls and other people they're related to, but it's not at all boring. Every conversation is filled with fun and interesting topics where anyone can usually relate with. Definitely a MUST WATCH for good laughs on the simple things.
It doesn't have much of a story, but the characters talk about some really good and funny stories about their life experiences. The best story I heard in this show is about the parentsof Konata.


The art, as what one can expect from Kyoto animation, is great! Everything looks nice and cute, and everything is animated well. They ran out of ideas on some things though and decided to recycle some stuff for some scene layouts.


The sounds are really good. The background suits every scene and the voices of the main cast are nice. The OP song is so good that people won't get tired of it even on the last episode. Also, the idea of having no ED was good. They just put on random, usually good stuff for the ED. Usually good because not all of the ED was interesting. Another sound problem is the use of a weird voice for some extra female characters. People will hear the same voice for those extras which is not good at all.


The character department is the best. Lucky Star has a wide variety of excellent characters. Everyone is so fun and so natural. A very outstanding cast.


This show is very enjoyable! Well the never ending conversations can be a little bit tiresome sometimes, but everything they talk about is interesting. It also has its really fun points like when they copy Initial D and when they visit Konata at her part time job. Many more can be seen and enjoyed in this show that's why it is considered one of the best.

First off, yes, this show has a reputation. And some people might hate it just because of that. But really it does live up to it's reputation.
Secondly, this is only my first review, so I hope I can manage to actually do a good job. If I'm confident in this review, I might just go on to write a few more.
Preface extended:
As another part of my preface, I'll go into my motto than an anime has to do something well to be a good anime. And if it does something really well, it's enough to be called a masterpiece. Now the more genres somethingdoes right, then the more the merrier. But it only takes one. 


And this show does that one thing really well. 


Now I'm not one of those people who goes around saying every genre of music has good music which I don't. And music and anime taste is subjective anyway. But for my own person tastes, and person feeling that every genre of anime has something to give, I felt a great deal of pleasure out of the elements this anime used. And has near single handedly shifted my anime fandom farther away from psychological and action anime which I used to be, and further towards comedy partialism.


I would hope to assume other people could share some of these same tastes. That's the point of a review is it not? I can only be subjective, not objective. This is art after all. But I will try my best.


For those of you who do not want to hear my rambling about good and bad, and the subjectivity and objectivity of art, skip the spoiler and start reading here.


1. Story.

I think this, like the other aspects of the show deserve a ten. I doesn't have anything complicated and intertwined deeply, no plot twists, no story hardly even. It's just an episodic slice of life anime. But it doesn't need it. And I love deep psychological story heavy anime. The pacing of this show and general fun is unparalleled hardly. Every scene of this this show basically stands on it's own as a good piece of anime work. Every little piece has been something I would want to watch several times, and often have since youtube, niconicodouga, and other sites have decided to break up scenes and mess with them.


It's a loveable, school based, otaku oriented school based story. It's nothing more, nothing less. It needs no more because randomness is part of the charm. It's fun because you just sit back and go along for the ride.


This show most deeply of any subjects, centers around otakudom. Now it's not uncommon for shows to do this. This show can also be slightly caustic and biting about it as well at times. Which is not uncommon in anime either. But never outside of the realm that it stops being fun at good natured. A thing that a lot of anime shows do not know when to stay within the realm of. Lucky Star allows you to think about being an otaku, without feeling bad.


I really wish I could go into more, but I'm rambling. In short, it's just pure fun. And in opinion, you just about have to have a broken fun gene to not like this anime.


2. Art.

You know when looking at a couple screenshots I made of this anime, it almost looked MSPainish. Meaning it looks like it could have been drawn in MSPaint. But it's every bit as brilliant as any anime artwork. You know back in days past, I used to think that maybe anime wasn't meant for MSPaint and CG and other computer related art making, because all the things I can saw at my local stores that used either one, looked nothing like anything that was anime or even could be anime. But I've learned otherwise, it's just that unfortunately the style that I love had not taken off in the United States then. And to make it to my point instead of rambling, is everything that the anime art style is.


It's MOE. It was designed to be moe. The characters are chibi looking, they have big eyes, unusual hair colors. Nothing out of the ordinary here, but Lucky Star does that art work really well. There's something almost iconic in it. As if to be some kind of mascot for moe. It's got some of the simple stuff that's not hard animation involved, such as exaggerated motions and puffs of smoke. But I don't know who you are and what you know about frame rates and whatever, but the character designs while chibified and such, are not lacking any shading they should, and everything I have found about the animation was to be smooth and superb. I have no complaints whatsoever about the artwork.


3. Sound.

Well...there's not much to go into for the sound. Which is good because this review is probably getting to be too long. There's nothing particularly epic or specially about the soundtrack. But it's cute and perfectly fitting, however simple. And the opening thing is downright famous. And for a reason, it's a simply genius bit of music. I've listened to the original and the remixes alike many hundreds of times throughout my life. And I'm sure to hit the thousands mark someday.


Actually, that was just the music I was thinking of. I forget that this is sound and not music rating. Well then it's time to go into voice acting.


The voices fit the characters in pretty much every way. And I only say pretty much because I'm in the habit of saying pretty much no matter what I'm saying. The voices absolutely fit in every way. From Konata's tomboyish otaku moe, to Kagami's tsundere moe, to every single side character. It's a cute overload. And that's why it's moe. And if you think it has any connecting with association with the artwork, just go listen to Konata's rendition of Cha-La Head Cha-La without any picture. You might be so overloaded with moe that you might faint and overdose.


4. Character.

It's a simple school life story, centered around a lovable otaku who the audience is set to agree with or relate to to some degree. She's you, the anime fan, especially if you're a big anime fan. If you're a girl, you'll probably relate to her, if you're a guy, you'll probably think she's your dream girl. That's the way she was designed and she makes and outstanding main character.


As for the other characters, they purposely got every anime character stereotype the could and played them out in various characters. And they did it in such a very charming spot on fashion, that it's just pure fun to watch these different archetypes play out and socially interact with each other in the same school.


Even the foreigner Patricia Martin, who plays out every single stereotype of Anime Otaku foreigners(and I mean every) is portrayed in only a positive light. It's almost like a fanservice to us this time. Japan is obviously growing more and more aware of it's otaku fanbase abroad.


5. Enjoyment.

Well I think that what pretty much covered so far, winds around what really motivates this show to be good. It doesn't have a complicated story. It doesn't have an epic soundtrack. It doesn't even have the most heavily shaded characters I've ever seen. But what it does have, makes all those other things pure 10's. And that's enjoyment. They all spiral toward one piece of pure fun in which every little piece of this show stands on it's own of fun. This is a show I will gladly watch several times throughout my lifetime and it will never get old.


6. Overall.

Well, I already sort of went into why everything in it tied into enjoyment. Or that enjoyment was the driving force. But allow me to ramble further. Some things get attention they don't deserve. Some things that are great go unnoticed. But Lucky Star is neither of these. It's a great anime that everyone knows about and actually deserved the attention.


I don't think I could criticize any one aspect of this show. Not one episode, not one scene. It is a masterpiece. It is a timeless classic. It deserves respect and reverence.

This series seems to inspire a great deal of controversy and disagreement.  Some love it, while others detest it.  It is funny that such an easygoing, lighthearted series would spawn such a range of reactions.  There are plenty of reviews out there, but despite this, I decided to add yet another.
I can see why this series would not appeal to everybody.  It has no overall story, and even the individual episodes have little, if any, plot.  The main portion of each episode consists of short snippets of the lives of the girls.  The humor is not the sort thatprovokes roaring laughter; for me, it seldom provokes more than a smile.  This series has numerous references to manga, anime, and other aspects of popular culture.  I certainly don't get all of them, and some of the humor might seem funnier to those who get most of the references.  Still, it is often clear from the context what type of anime (or other cultural product) the reference suggests.  The lack of plot and the relatively light humor aren't weaknesses; these characteristics are essential to the general atmosphere of the series.


This series is driven entirely by the characters and the situations.  The first few episodes are a bit slow to get going; it takes time to introduce the characters, and it takes time for the audience to become familiar with them.  At first, I found the series a little dull, but I decided to be patient with it and see where it would lead me, and before long, I found myself sucked into it, identifying with some of the characters and enjoying its simple, relaxing atmosphere.  The art is stylistically appropriate to the series; the characters are simply drawn, and (as I'm sure everybody expects) ridiculously cute.  The backgrounds are nicely detailed.  The music within each episode is mostly simple and understated, tuneless tunes that are designed to build up the atmosphere and not get in the way of the dialogue - again appropriate to the series.


A series like this needs good characters, and "Lucky Star" has them.  Once the characters are sufficiently introduced, there isn't a great deal of development, but in a series without a plot, traditional development isn't likely to happen and wouldn't be appropriate anyway.  Out of the group of main characters, Konata and Kagami have the strongest personalities, and I identify closely with both of them; perhaps this is the primary reason why I enjoyed the series.  Konata is a seemingly exaggerated otaku.  However, she isn't as exaggerated as some may think; I have known many people with severe otaku-like obsessions, and I have such tendencies myself.  She seems perfectly believable.  Kagami is a serious girl, devoted to her studies but willing to have fun when the work is done.  She is a tsundere, albeit a rather moderate one.  The light conflict between these two is a recurring theme in the series.  I feel like both characters live within me; my inner Kagami wants me to take the practical aspects of life more seriously, while my inner Konata wants to write a review of "Lucky Star" on this website.  Perhaps many anime fans have such an inner conflict, and they can identify with these two characters and the humorous situations that arise from their interactions.  The other characters are more typical, and some of the supporting characters are comic exaggerations.  They add to the atmosphere and add variety to the situations, but Kagami and Konata steal the show.


The "Lucky Channel" segments at the end contrast with the main program.  The humor is darker and more in-your-face, and the sense of parody is strong.  Akira is a parody of the typical temperamental celebrity, and she allows her bad temper to come out during these segments.  Her cute, cheery, and annoying high-pitched voice is an act; in reality, she is a bitch.  I suppose this is a parody of the idol culture in Japan, but it could easily apply to temperamental Hollywood actresses or even opera singers dating back to the seventeenth century, so it has universal appeal.  I enjoy how Akira's bad temper develops and blows up over the course of the series.


Overall, I came to enjoy this series considerably even though it had a rough start.  It is a lighthearted, random, dialogue-based slice-of-life comedy, and it doesn't try to be anything else.  Perhaps some who don't like it either don't like this style or want it to be something else.  It certainly isn't for everyone, and I can see how some people would find it boring, but those who like random everyday situations and light humor with a simple, relaxing atmosphere might want to give it a try.

Lucky Star is a kind of show that half of people would love, and the other half would purely hate. 
There is basically no story which makes this anime, well, should I say different. It really depends on the person. Since I was a little kid I always loved those "Slice of Life" shows.  The "story" is basically the life of Konata Izumi (the main charcter on my opinion) and her three friends: Miyuki, Kagami and Tsukasa. 
The girls get on with their ordinary every-day lives, sometimes experiencing new things and having fun. 
As for the art, the characters do not really have muchdetail, which is different, but does not mae a bad impression. The backgrounds are fairly smple too. As for the characters, maybe if the look it self isn't so sofisticated, the personalities are very different.\n
The characters all have their own things, that are great about them. I wouldn't likke to tell you what they are but, Konata would have a good impression on any young beginner otaku. While Miyuki and Kagami will have a good impression on the clever kind, Tsukasa finally is the lazy one, funny and clumsy. All the supporting characters also have their own twist, which definately have been put effort into. \n
I enjoyed this anime very much and I plan on rewatching it soon. No matter how many times you rewatch an episode of Lucky Star, you will never get bored of it. \n
The sound is great, the background mudic is not always noticeable, but when you listen into it it really shows the mood of the scene. As for me, I watched the dub, and I should say the voices were fairly good. \n
Overall I would rate Lucky Star 9/10. The two points that were taken away, are really because of the ending. It was fairly ruined, but you'll see why when you watch it. The ending songs weren't that good either. But overall I'd call it a pretty good anime. I would be really happy ifthey made another season.\n

This anime goes purely along the slice of line genre. The plot may be boring at the start, and the focus of the story doesn't seem to portray initially. Characters were seen chatting for a long long time. However, if you survive through the first episode of this anime, you will gradually understand the storyline and enjoy it.
The art is a kind on its own, but i will say that not everyone will find that it's to their own taste. The art is simple and clear, bringing forth the necessary expressions when needed. Furthermore since this storyline is very slice of life based, complicated animationmay not be needed, so I feel that it is something that can be overlooked. 


One thing I not so satisfied is the way they chose to voice the not-so-important male and female characters with a weird voice (sounds like woman/man), and they are reusing it quite a lot of times. The background music is simple and short but I find it lacking it variety. Of course the seiyuus for the main characters are really great though. 


The characters of Lucky Star each have a unique personality that depicts not only the Otaku society but also normal high school girls. It is fun as the series proceeds and you get to see more and more characters, all varying in personality. Some are dorky enough to get you laughing. 


This is definitely a recommended anime for Otakus. All you need to do is sit back and relax and have a good laugh at the jokes the characters crack and the conversations going on in their daily school life. However, some of the content of the jokes requires knowledge on some anime or lifestyle of an Otaku. It involves specific terms sometimes that are hard to understand. 


The rewatch value for this anime can be rated really high because the more you watch it, the funnier it gets as you understand the content fully.

Chocalate cornets. That is all it took to get hooked into this hilarious anime.
The biggest factor in the enjoyment to this anime is the characters. The characters are very well thought out, especially in the case of Izumi Konata. The character of Konata is so well written that it seems like she was created in a lab with a formula to please every anime watcher. The Hiiragi Kagami character adds as not only a compliment to Konata, but as a great centerpiece for adding social commentary and as many characters feed off of Kagami as they do Konata. Although the show names 4 characters asthe main characters, Lucky Star does raise Konata and Kagami to a higher level than it does Hiiragi Tsukasa or Takara Miyuki. Thats not to say that they aren't enjoyable when they are on screen. Tsukasa works as a perfect compliment to both Konata and Kagami, which is surprising considering the the polar opposite feel of thier personalities. Miyuki works well in giving "moe" to Lucky Star. Lucky Star is not about moe so she ends up being the butt of many jokes. Miyuki, however does manage to fit very well whenever she is on screen. The show also offers an abundance of supporting that give Miyuki and Tsukasa a run for heir money. Every one of them adds something different. The formuila does not change for the show with so many characters insteads builds on it and makes it seem very natural.


The story is not bad because well, there isn't one. The lack of a a progressing plot does not hurt the show because it's not focused on a plot, its focus is on its characters. 


The art of Lucky Star is very basic. Nothing will really wow the viewers. The simplicity of the art is fit because the show is not complex in terms of development, in both a story or character. scenes where the art changes are typically for parody. This results from many references to other animes (Suzumiya Haruhi, Full Metal Panic, Street Fighter, Initial D, and many more).


The soundtrack for Lucky Star may only be as enjoyable as the show. The opening theme "Motteke Sailor Uniform" is a very fast paced, and upbeat song that actually does work well in transitioning into the show."Motteke Sailor Uniform" however, does not work well as the shows introduction, but if you like the show the song will grow on you.


In the end there not much changes from the beginning but as long as you became attatched these characters than its been an extremely enjoyable time.

The "Slice of Life" anime series is one where nothing is required, and what I mean when I say nothing is required is that we as viewers have nothing more to do than sit back and watch.  Certain shows introduce complex backdrops and settings, intricate story lines, historical figures that require a certain amount of research to fully understand, or character relationships that develop and introduce more than meets the eye as the story progresses.  I enjoy these characteristics in animes tremendously as they challenge us as a viewer to imagine and go beyond our basic understanding of "normal" to fully appreciate thestory being told in front of us.  That being said, sometimes its also nice to indulge ourselves into a realm of carefree and fun, where consequences are void and mindless merriment is abundant.  Lucky Star is one of those animes where we come to it for no other reason than to just decompress into an uncomplicated world of enjoyment, bare of an truly complicated plot or story line.  But does it deliver the guilty pleasure we desire?  I will examine this anime and attempt to give you an educated opinion as to the merits of Lucky Star, however, in the end you are the true master in the decision to watch the anime.  That being said, let us waste no more time as I now present to you my review of Lucky Star.



Story:  Remember, this is slice of life comedy, not an epic...


To try and write a story review for Lucky Star is difficult, as there is no "real" overarching story line to pay attention to, at least not like Code Geass, Death Note, or any other story driven anime.  The story centers around the misadventures of a group of friends while also introducing other characters who play a role to better advance the story of the other central characters.  From this, we see the true nature of story in Lucky Star comes from the characters themselves, not the events that are around them.  So how does this effect the overall story.  Not bad in the end.  There are plenty of characters in Lucky Star to where there is enough to keep us engaged from episode to episode and even the supporting characters help move along each episode's story.  There is no actual story in this anime though, now of course we could engage in a discussion on how the underlying story deals with maturity and coming of age for high school students as they realize that good friends and family are all you need to live a successful life, but we are going to look at the surface level of story.  Each episode for the most part deals with a new story line and there is no epiphanies or dramatic shockers that will get viewers like us going.  In the end though, its the life and times of each character that truly makes for a good story and this is quite enough to forgive no central plot and enjoy what is in front of us any given episode. (8/10)



Art:  We are here for the comedy and enterprise, not breathtaking visuals...


When we look at the target audience for something like Lucky Star we would most likely conclude that its base would be a younger generation and most who are looking for something lighthearted, not something gritty and full of detail.  This is what we get in Lucky Star animation style, a simple animated world full of "cuteness" and playful image concepts.  There is no extravagant works of art here, as simple is the key word, and you most likely will not walk away fully taken away by some visual art seen from this anime.  All in all though, it gets the job done.  (6/10)



Sound: Lots of filler music, but some really exceptional voice acting work...


Music is one of those things you can sort of get away with depending on your product.  In movies or shows where you have a lot of drama or action, music can help enhance that experience ten fold as long as you fit the right music in at the right time (listen to almost any Hans Zimmer soundtrack).  But in comedies where it is more about dialog and interaction, music usually takes a back seat as there are other mechanics to take advantage of our emotions.  Lucky Star is in that category, the one where music isn't as much of a priority, as lots of the music in the anime are just simple melodies that play in the background and just become fillers so that the experience can seem complete, same with the sound effects.  The themes that play in the beginning and end are great, but this anime's soundtrack, should one exist, will not be a line item in my budget any time soon.

Sound has two functions though, not just the music and sound effects but also voice acting, with this anime having excellent talent behind the microphone.  Both the Japanese and American voice actors do a fine job of portraying their characters, breathing life into each character to make them seem human and someone we can relate too.  Good voice acting is just as important as good acting on stage or on screen as this is the way we can hear and interpret characters we see, as there is no other conduit to see if the person portraying the character is a good fit (imagine Danny Devito voicing Darth Vader instead of James Earl Jones).  And in this anime there is not shortage for good voice acting, and each actor and actress fits into their character well, putting no doubts or thoughts in the back of our head challenging us as to whether or not the person voicing the character was the right choice.  (8/10)



Character:  A great bunch of characters you can't help but love...


This is probably the best attribute of Lucky Star, and it delivers on a large scale.  The main characters of Kagami, Tsukasa, Myuki and Konata embody the strength that a powerful and well structured main character cast can have.  Whether it be Kagami's strong and strighforward attitude coupled with a girlish inner-complex, Tsukasa's loveable and naive nature, Miyuki's scholastic prowess, or Konata's tomboyish and nerdish attitude that acts as the central character and also as a symbol of no matter who or what you are you as long as you act with conviction and aren't afraid to embrace who you are you will live a fulfilling life.  All of these main characters serve to breath life into the story, mainly on their interactions not just internally with each other but also externally with other characters.  Events such as the characters and how each differs while at an anime convention, talking with family, interacting with people outside of their normal group, buying items at a store, or any other instance reinforces and creates the entertainment within Lucky Star.  As we discussed earlier in the Story part of the review, this animes story is really as strong as its characters, and while there may not be a great deal of story arc, their is lots of character arc to which I believe moves this little slice of life comedy into a story capturing the trials and maturity of four high school girls as they prepare for the road ahead.  Well done Lucky Star, well done.  (9/10)



Enjoyment:  It's safe, I promise...


Usually when you are contemplating watching anything, the one question that lingers in the back of your mind is "will I actually enjoy it"?  As for Lucky Star, as long as you can handle no overarching story line, high school slice of life, comedy, and just of bunch of characters having a good time than you will enjoy Lucky Star.   Remember, you're coming to Lucky Star so you can unwind and partake in some fun and relaxation that requires nothing from you, other than your undivided attention.  The characters and voice acting alone should be enough to create an enjoyable experience for yourself, so there shouldn't be any worries.  (8/10)



Overall:  Fun for the whole family...


In the end, Lucky Star does well and really as long as you come prepared for adventures with a bunch of high school kids, anyone can find enjoyment in this anime.  As already stated, the story is not complex and deals in an episode-by-episode manner, the art is what it is, music fills in gaps while voice acting breaths talent into their respective characters, the cast each has a story to tell and it's well told, and everyone can take away at least a little enjoyment from the  experience.  Overall I believe that Lucky Star is a very good anime and should anyone be looking for something to watch on any given weekend afternoon, this is the perfect ticket.  (8/10)

Lucky Star can be best described as "an anime version of Seinfield that focuses on four teenage high school girls with lots of moe," which is really the best way to describe it. If anyone have watched the 1990s classic American slice-of-life sitcom, Seinfield, it is quite infamous for having a lot of dialogue in the series that focuses on random and humorous topics. And there is a reason why Seinfield is referred to as "a series about nothing."
Similarly, Lucky Star have a lot of nonsensical dialogue and conversations of different topics. Like many slice-of-life anime, there isn't a definite plot. However, the series ismostly centered around Japanese pop culture, the seiyuu references, and the otaku culture. As such, the series is primarily meant to be targeted towards the anime otaku in Japan. However, the series can still be enjoyable even for the non-otaku and western viewers (I, myself, while I consider to have interests and enjoy anime, I don't consider myself to be a hardcore otaku because I also have other interests outside of video games and anime. And I happen love and enjoy the series). The series does have a lot of quirky humor to it, but at least it covers broad range of topics and issues within numerous dialouge that makes it enjoyable. The ending is also enjoyable as well, as it does connect into how the OP of the series came to be.


The only downside to the series is the first episode. The first scene in the very first episode shows Konata, Miyuki, and Tsuakas spending about 8 minutes talking about food. This scene can shut off many first-time viewers there, but after watching that scene, the series gets more comical and fast-paced.


Now for the characters. The characters are mostly flat characters. Their personalities doesn't change a lot, so I'd give a lower score there. However, each character have their own uniqueness that makes the series enjoyable. For example, the Hiiragi twins, Kagami and Tsukasa, is something to bring up. Both Kagami and Tsukasa can be comparable to the ying-yang concept. Kagami is a jaded, sarcastic, cynical tsundere who have a tedency to snap easily of the four main characters, but she also happens to be the most rational character in the series. Likewise, Tsukasa is more a kind-hearted, sweet, gentle, and more emotional girl who happens to be a heavy sleeper, forgetful, and quite clumsy at times. The Hiiragi twins comparison is also pointed out in the series in regards to their cooking styles as well (Kagami is more of a below-average cook while Tsukasa excels on cooking). Another example of character uniqueness is Konata and her cousin, Yutaka. Both happen to look younger than their actual high school age due to their height (the later happen to suffer some sort of an illness that limits her constitution and physical abilties). This is referenced throughout the series and joked multiple times. Konata mentions that she is highly aware of her own height and physique, and her self-awareness of this leads her to the conclusion that being a loiicon magnet is an inevitable fate. This kind of twist help viewers to understand the issue of lolicon (and issues regarding to child pornography and abuse), and spin this into a more humorous and satirical way.


Bear in note that not many people would enjoy the characters mainly due to the usage of moe and cuteness within the characters. Of course, moe is the probably the entire point of the series.


And speaking about Yutaka and Konata, the episode where Konata talks about her deceased mother, Kanata (who happens to have a similar appearance to Konata), with her father (who happens to have lolicon tendencies) is probably the most heartwarming moment of the series.


Now for the Japanese/English soundtrack comparsion. Personally, there are great qualities of both the English and Japanese soundtrack. But as a dub fan, I personally prefer the dub mainly because Lucky Star is a fast-paced anime with lots of dialogue that allowed me to connect with the characters better. Since the series take references on Japanese pop culture and the seiyuus, most of the jokes would be lost. However, the series also take liberal references to the Haruhi Suzumiya series (another one of Kyoto Animation's works and the series is licensed by Bandai who also licensed the Haruhi series), so not all the jokes are lost. Besides, the dub is done by Bang Zoom! (who also have done the Haruhi dub) who uses the very same voice actors of the Haruhi dub, so I can give credit there dub. Also, the dub is not exact word-to-word translation and there are some jokes that need to be replaced in the dub to make it as enjoyable as the Japanese version. For example, in the dub, Akira Kogami mentions that Minoru Shiraishi sounds like a "nerdy turtle." This is because the English VA of Minoru Shiraishi, Sam Riegel (who happens to voice another one of Minoru Shiraishi's roles, Taniguchi from Haruhi Suzumiya), also happens to voice Donatello from the 2003 Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles series. I'd say it all comes down to your own personal preferences (although there are some Japanese who does enjoy the English dub of Lucky Star).


For the voice acting, I'd enjoyed both the English and Japanese voice acting. I enjoyed Aya Hirano's voice acting of Konata because makes Konata sound really cute (particularly the Timotei scene), but I happen to enjoy Wendee Lee's voice acting because she gives Konata a "geeky" voice that fits into Konata's otaku personality. I happen to enjoy both Hynden Walch's and Shizuka Hasegawa's voice acting of Yutaka Kobayakawa. However, if I'm forced to choose between which one is better, I'd say Hydnen Walch because she manages to make Yutaka sound cute without being over the top cute AND sound naturally in English. I enjoyed Kari Wahlgren's VA on Kagami because she manages to make her sound more angrier and sarcastic than the Japanese version. The only voice acting I don't like in both Japanese and English version was Patricia Martin, as she sounds like a badly-pitched Minnie Mouse (funny that the character is based out of and voiced by Patricia Ja Lee). Of course, I'm pretty sure that was intentional by the producers, mainly because Patricia is suppose to satirical to the American otaku fanbase.


The series is available in both Engilsh and Japanese soundtrack. Unfortunately, Bandai has yet uploaded (or unwilling to do so) the episodes of Lucky Star dubbed and subbed online. So you'd probably either be forced to watch the illegal uploads, or go out and buy the Lucky Star Complete Collection. If you are looking for an anime series with lots of cuteness and quirky humor, this is something I would recommend. It would be nice to have a second season of Lucky Star. However, the ending comes out really smoothly and if there was a second season, it would most likely be focused on the other four girl group (Yutaka, Patrica, Hiyori, and Minami). That is mainly because the main four girl group (Konata, Tsukasa, Kagami, and Miyuki) happens to be seniors by the time the last episode aired. So it would be highly unnecessary that a high-school comedy based series to continue to focus on them into college. Highly improbable, but that is something that could be interesting.


From my Mania.com blog: http://www.mania.com/aodvb/blog.php?b=3215

This anime was great! If you watch other anime, ALOT, this will be a fantastic anime to watch. There are tons of references to One Piece, Initial D, Code Geass and even .//hack! It's funny and its pretty much 100% AWESOME. 
i don't recemmend it tho, if you don't know much about Japan culture!

The only slice of life anime I would ever actually make time to watch. Yes, it's that good. Revolves around the daily events of four high-school aged girls: the otaku, the moe genius, the tsundere, and her carefree sister. No real plotline on an episode to episode basis, but with characters as colorful as these,  hilarious scene to scene progression, and insanely awesome chibi art, who needs plot? Fast-paced and in your face, this is the epitome of entertainment for entertainment's sake, and I mean that in the best way possible.

I thought real long and hard about those extremely high scores up there, believe me. I absolutely hate the fact that i'm giving it such a high score, but I can't give it anything less. Lucky Star is an amazing anime and one of my favorites of all time. I'm a sucker for character-driven anime, and this is right up my alley.
It's impossible not to compare this to Azumanga Daioh. While Azumanga Daioh is definitely funnier, Lucky Star has a sort of wit and cutting edge air about it. Not many people will get all of the jokes, and it definitely helps to understand Japanese(you lose a lot in the translation), but that makes it even more unique and special. 


The characters in Lucky Star are oustanding, and while not quite up to par with Azumanga Daioh, there are more of them. And like Azumanga Daioh, they are all extremely interesting and likeable. Not a boring or useless character to be seen.


The most interesting character is probably Konata Izumi, the blue-haired, free spirited otaku. You're not sure if you'd prefer her as your wife or your daughter, but either way she's more moe-inducing than the girl who is designed to be stereotypically moe, and that says alot. 


Her dad is a creepy pervert, and the anime deals with it well; some might condone his behavior, but Lucky Star doesn't. It recognizes that he is a problem, but at the same time he's just a human like the rest of us. Perfect.


There are too many characters to list here, but rest assured that you won't be disappointed by any of them.


Even though most of the humor comes from subtle observations on human behavior, otaku in-jokes, and wit, there is still some Azumanga Daioh type humor present that can be very funny. It can also be very touching, and one of the later episodes had me literally crying. 


And who can forget the opening credits? They are legendary.


Being based on a four-panel comic makes the anime translation a daunting task, but Lucky Star pulls it off splendidly, much better than Azumanga Daioh. The progression is fluid and perfectly paced. The empty space is put to good use with a 'lucky channel' corner at the end of every episode that is separate from the main show but still very entertaining.


And the ending credits...the later episodes have the voice actors doing typically insane Japanese things in live action. Legendary!


And speaking of the seiyuus, they did an amazing job. Lucky Star and Azumanga Daioh really set the standard for voice acting. And who would have thought that Aya Hirano, basically a bubble-gum pop star, would be so talented? Her work as Konata steals the show amongst a field of excellence. Our pop stars can't act their way out of a wet paper bag!


Some don't like the art, and I suppose it is truly in the eye of the beholder, but I personally loved it. Everyone looks very young (even the adults) but they are all well drawn and their facial expressions are extremely well done. Especially Konata. 


All in all, this was an amazing anime and a classic in my book. Completely entertaining with an unforgettable and loveable cast with great voice acting, it is downright hilarious, and its replay value is neverending. Nothing else to ask for.

Sound 10/10

Music is great. though I don't really stay and listen to the theme songs in the ending credits. Sounds in the story are very quiet which balances the story theme.

Characters are the one of the best. However most of the female characters aren't introduced until half way through the anime and there aren't many male characters. But I not complaining. Overall this is a good anime. A definetly want to watch. I give it a better rating if there was less boring talk scenes but besides that it's great. You gotta watch it.

Lucky Star was overall a very good anime, and although there is little to no story,the pure joy you get from their jokes more than makes up for the lack of plot. I'm not one to usually watch an anime without *some* sort of plot, but this one took me by surprise when it actually held me throughout the series.
 I began Lucky Star thinking that ii would turn out to just leave me unsatisfied because of the lack of plot, like some ecchi anime that I've watched, but that's just me.   
I gave the sound a nine because I'm not really anexpert on sound and I don't really get the meaning of it unless they're talking about the seiyuu's (voice actor's) in which case the main characters were good except for that one guy that does random, not main character voices, that has an annoying voice. But that, too is just me. (" -_- )


You may be asking yourself, why did she give the story a 3 if there is no story, well, I gave it a three because:

    1) I just can't give anything a completely horrible score when it left me all warm and  fuzzy inside 

And

    2) It sort of reminded me of life, only all the happy, sad, mad, confused, and all that jazz, parts were cut out leaving the parts that make you laugh out loud and want to pee your pants because of their faces and how real it seems, because you yourself can relate to a character in some way or another.


I gave the art a ten because I thought that the characters were cute and it was colorful and appealing to the eye.   


The characters were given a ten because I really liked two in particular, Konata and Kagami because they were the ones that made me laugh the most (^.^).
