This may just be the most "pure" slice of life anime ever.
Lucky☆Star! An anime about cute girls, high school, and pure random-ness. Basically, it's really hard to even give this anime a four in the story department, as there really isn't a "story" here. And honestly, I'm really surprised of the outcome. There's a lot of random stuff that happens on this show. Mainly the main four just living their lives and doing what normal high school girls might do. But honestly what made it really fun to watch was the "lucky channel" segment at the end of the show, as well as the reallystrange ending with the guy singing (that really was funny, though). But honestly I have to say I'm impressed with what we're given with such a shallow basis.


At first, I had a very bad feeling about this one. I had the impression that these characters were going to be your typical, and uninspired bunch who have the same traits that we've all seen before. But there's a slight change with them. For me, it's the atmosphere that the characters give off. Most of them *are* your typical "tsundere" type or your "shy-cute" type, but they seem to have more than *just* that. There's also a healthy diversity of personas here, you'll see what I mean.


Art and sound are both pretty good for the age. The art can sometimes be very plain looking, but it doesn't bother me. As for the OP, I can see why it's so infamous; it's damn good. 


There's a lot of stuff to be seen. Lots of really random stuff, but it's all very fun and honestly never really gets boring. Has a killer OP, really great roster of characters, and overall just a good atmosphere. I recommend you watch this if you're looking for a chilled out anime with *no* real story but just looking for a fun time.

Lucky Star is truly a slice of life anime. First of all, I noticed most of my friends who didn't like Lucky Star, didn't like because of it's slow pace, and that's completely fine. I understand some people like some kind of humor and everything, so I'll start by the humor.
The humor in this show is different from what we usually see, it's more based on that "Haha, I know that feeling" type of jokes, and situations that involves already knowing the characters, because if you don't know their personality, about 70% of the jokes won't work.
Know those jokes on a stand-up comedy show? It'skinda like that.


Now, the characters, as I mentioned, each has their unique traits of personality and are as relatable as adorable, but that doesn't mean you never saw characters like them in any anime ever, or that you'll necessarily like all of them. But still, they're very well done, and honestly, Konata is one of the best anime characters I've ever seen. In general, they all develop a really good relationship with who's watching.


Another thing I'd like to point out is that most of my friends dropped this show on episode 1 (actually, most didn't even FINISHED episode 1), I understand why but please, stay and watch at least 3 or 5 episodes, because seriously, it might take some time to you to get used to this show. It happened to me, I was kinda bored on episode 1, but at the end I laughed, and some days later (I kinda forgot about this show actually) I got back and watched episode 2 to episode 5, and I started laughing more frequently and getting used to the humor, and remember I mentioned that the character's personalities are important in this show? Yeah, it takes some time to you to "know" them better, that's part of why you need to watch more than one or two episodes.


Well, on the technical part I'm not very specialist, except by the sound, and man, it's wonderful. Voice acting is great and BGM is really great.

About the art, I don't know much about this to judge, but I love it, character design is wonderful and expression faces are standout.


On story, there's very little, but there's some traits (as Konata and her family, for example) that I love, but mostly, it's normal stories, you won't see other worldly events or plot twists, this show is more like meeting friends and interacting with them. You know that random conversation that friends have sometimes? Yeah, that kind of thing.


And about enjoyment, I agree that sometimes it can get a bit too slow, so I don't recommend you give it a first or second chance when you're sleepy.

TL;DR version: Lucky☆Star is the anime equivalent of a white noise machine.
Long version:
I've put off Lucky Star for a very long time.
Honestly speaking, my younger teenage self in the late 2000's would have bashed the crap out of this series and probably rate it a 2 or something, but we're not asking what younger me thinks. Younger me is a dumbass after all.
Present me in his mid to late 20's somewhat enjoyed LS.
The thing about Lucky Star is that it's not supposed to be over-the-top entertaining (in the main show anyways, as opposed to Lucky Channel, but we'll get to that later). Lucky Star isvery mellow in atmosphere, even the background music is consistent, simple and kept at the minimum to maintain that mellow feeling. There are no major conflicts or fantastical point in a plot. Only about 2 episodes out of 24 does it show a serious tone. It's not necessarily something you binge watch (although I did, but whatever). The layout of each episode can vary, but once again, for approximately three quarters of the show, it's very tranquil and relaxing in nature. So if you're more about adrenaline fueled excitement and burst out laughing, or full on cry or rage, this show isn't for you.\n\n
Most of the characters aren't as expressive and entertaining as you might think, contrary to how the opening song has portrayed them. A lot of their conversations revolve around mundane activities, situations and objects. In a way, it makes you, the audience, feel like you are the third wheel amongst a group of friends. You listen to their complaints or thoughts, but don't really input your own, making some episodes extremely hard and boring to watch (most notably, episode 1 and their "food talk"). At least, that's the way it is for me.\n
The characters barely have much personality. Besides Izumi and a few others, all of the characters are really bland. I was disappointed that new side characters gets introduced RIGHT IN THE MIDDLE of the series. Sadly, they're a bit more interesting than the main girls we are used to seeing (with the exception of Izumi of course). Izumi unfortunately has the responsibility of pulling the main show together with her geeky personality, but when you have the slightly more interesting of the bland bunch trying to make the show entertaining, you're gonna have a bad time. I like Izumi, but even she isn't that amazing as a character.\n\n
Its humor heavily uses references, some of it VERY obscure unless you're well-versed in said reference. The core of their humor is how the topic relates to the audience. LS is too reliant on the audience's understanding of the characters' plight, which doesn't make good entertainment and causes the delivery to be quite weak, although a few did catch me by surprise and I actually laughed. A joke won't unfold itself without a good delivery. However, giving credit where it's due, it's actually quite original in a sense as well. I did enjoy the few running gags that they've installed, like how the nameless side characters all have the same distinctive voice of a middle aged man or an old woman, no matter their actual age. I've also enjoyed how they handle the ending songs and the use of live action. Half of the time they're hits or misses. \n\n
Finally, Lucky Channel. The Lucky Channel segments have their ups and downs. It's the complete opposite in atmosphere and the characters are, in my opinion, overly expressive and the transition from Lucky Star to Lucky Channel just ruins the flow of the show. First Lucky Star puts me in a relaxed state, then immediately slaps me with the ostentatious Akira of Lucky Channel is just a terrible transition between scenes. If Lucky Channel was somehow made into a separate side story, then I would be fine with. The only thing I like about Lucky Channel was the interaction between the anchors and their development, but even that can only be tolerated for a certain amount of episodes before you grow tired of it.\n\n
All in all, Lucky☆Star is pretty average. It's a 6 at best and a 3 at worst.

I honestly did not know what I was expecting when I first watched this anime. When I started watching the first episode, I found myself listening to a conversation on which has no effect on my life whatsoever, and somehow ended up liking it.
I don't know what makes this anime so prime, if it's because of the comedic-randomness that comes and go every now and then, then this may be one of the gems you could find in the pitch-black coal patch. If you have nothing to do anymore, or just completed watching a sad/scary anime and need some cooldown time, then this is theanime for you.


The story line that this anime has is much more of random occurrences than of a a solid story type, since it is a comedic anime, of course. Nonetheless, the director has done a decent job in keeping the momentum on check and at the same time making it amusing, because one of the biggest problems of comedy type animes is that eventually, the joke tires out itself. But with random nonsensical situations and horseplay, the anime never seems to lose the momentum, and still is hilarious the second time around.


The artistic value of the anime is nothing much to report to, other from the fact that it does a great job in emphasizing the cuteness of the characters somehow.


The characters on this anime is what gives this anime its publicity. Konata, Kagami and Tsukasa form the trio of folks that never seem to disappoint in giving you a laugh-dosage whenever they pull off a gag or from simply forgetting to do their homeworks.


After watching the series, I ended up enjoying it, and eventually gave it an almost perfect score because I enjoyed it to such an extent. I would recommend this to anybody who is itching for a laugh or basically has nothing to do.

Going into Lucky☆Star (yeah,  I added the star) I didn't know what to expect. You know, as soon as the episode started my blood was pumping; I was hyped up! I was getting ready to enjoy the ride of a life time: an adventure through Lucky☆Star. After being hit with a fairly upbeat opening theme, I was already at the edge of my seat. Then the actual show came. I sat there, my mouth opened, my eyes opened wide. A moment later, my voice finally mustered enough energy to let out words which echoed a crossed the  heavens:
"Yo. They just talked about howto eat a flippin' pastry. Flap this shizzle. I'm dropping this."


I pulled up myanimelist (I'm a noob around here, I know) without hesitation, went to Lucky☆Star, jotted down my first episode watched, and pulled up another episode.


Wait, I did what? Well, shoot. Before I knew it, Lucky☆Star was set as Completed. Why you ask? Because I quite enjoyed it, duh. I admit, the show is a bit overrated but there were some redeeming foshizzle points that gave me an excuse NOT to drop this, one of which being the story.


Ok, I lied. There is no story. But here's the thing, having no plot was actually a plus to this whole "cute girls doing cute things" formula. You know, I'm occasionally stressed out because of school and this show helped me settle down and cool off because there doesn't seem to be any conflict or problems or evil voodoo stuff going on here. None of that "Ack. Nooo. She's going to die. Now I'm bummed out." No no no. In here, only good seems to come out of this world. Lucky☆Star isn't one of those shows where you can talk about hours on end with friends (unless.. you actually do that then uh.. ok), but rather a show you just pick up whenever and finish whenever. No cliffhangers, no drama, no problem. Instead of a story, we were given stories (damn right, PLURAL).


But how can a plotless show provide a story? That doesn't make any sense. Well, I can argue that the characters themselves make up the story as we move, each second, towards the end of an episode. So instead of giving us a set script to follow, we are given the luxury of an open script. The characters are mere catalysts who, when put together, create a nice gateway to a slice of life. The characters basically form a team (not literally) and they work as a team to accomplish a common goal. But often times there are some teammates who just causes a disruption in the work flow of the team. Enter a plethora of supporting female characters roughly around the second half of the series. At some point, it seemed like we were getting some character development out of these newly introduced characters. I just felt it was unnecessary since the development felt rushed. And since they were introduced so far in the series thus giving them a smaller window of screen time than the four main characters, I really didn't care for them even after their "character development."


Despite have a seemingly large cast of characters, the voice acting (with the exception of Patricia Martin; sorry Nozomi) were pretty fitting for each of the characters. The soundtrack seemed fitting in every scene, despite the track sounding a bit boring. The art wasn't bad either, even IF the art style is a bit simplistic. For a show like this, the simplistic art style was fitting.


For me, some episodes were just plain boring. Some episodes were interesting. Regardless, I quite enjoyed the Lucky☆Star. There were a lot of references that I've caught and it was fun to see this show take a comedic spin on them.


In the end of the day, Lucky☆Star really isn't for everyone. If you already hate moeblobs then you certainly won't magically wake up one day looking forward to watching this. You aren't going to be laughing your Ash off, but rather crack a smile here and there. And this is definitely a show you'd watch with a couple of thug buddies.


"Yo man what we watchin'?"

"Damn. ****'s about to get real up in here. We watchin' Lucky Star"


You should have an open mind when going into this show and really have no high expectations if you truly want to enjoy the show more or less. Lucky☆Star is not a master piece. It's not garbage. It is, however, a decent watch which will only appeal to certain groups of people.

Before I start let me tell you guys a story. Se-ra-fuku " all of the sudden in the class with my friends. Then all of my otaku friends went silent andone of them told me "YOU DO REALIZE THAT SONG IS ABOUT WANTING TO WEAR A SAILOR UNIFORM AND A CUTER SKIRT....". I stop singing and the whole group went silent so we just concluded that we never heard anyone singing and basically that never happened. So that is one of my regrets in life and now I'm closing it as part of my history that never happened!!!


Lucky Star is best described by the famous "Seinfeld" show quote " A show about nothing". Now before you dismiss this as another generic slice of life, which technically your right but in my defense its done good.


Story: 6/10


"Everybody's doing something, we'll do nothing." which is also a quote from Seinfeld that I'm pretty sure the creator of Lucky Star was thinking at that time he was making Lucky Star. This anime is plot-less or more appropriately there is no story because  all the plot is in Miyuki, Right guys, No, okay I'll stop. Personally I always have high hopes for slice of life genre type of anime because I want to see them pull off the million dollar challenge and that is "To make normal everyday life events, interesting". So normally I have high hopes for this anime but it gives us the mundane yet fun events of life. Sure it is funny and comedic but i want something more interesting. I think of Lucky Star as a lower type of sitcom because it does feel like a sitcom but sitcoms have series of events that connects or has a relation to another event in one episode which is very interesting while Lucky Star is just a random collection of everyday life of different high school girls.


Art: 9/10


Well one word to describe the art, MOE!!!! I am losing my manliness as I was watching this anime specially whenever Tsukasa is making a Moe scene so I have to punch a wall to regain my manliness. Besides the art of the characters, the background and others are rather simplistic.


Sound: 10/10


It only have a random songs at the end but, Oh my God, the opening. The opening is titled "Motteke! Se-ra-fuku" and even if it is translated to English I still cannot completely understand the song. All I know about the opening is that it is catchy and one of my friend said it is about sailor uniforms and skirts.... Of all the catchy songs this one has tormented me because I sang this in front of my friends and its meaning is wanting to wear a sailor uniform and skirts. However it is still great because every time I hear Lucky Star that song is the first thing to play in my mind then suddenly I am singing it. WARNING THE OPENING WILL HAUNT YOU FOR YEARS


Character: 9/10


Though the show doesn't have a plot it still have some interesting characters From the first 4 character batch to the 2nd 4 character batch. I'll start with the 2nd batch:


Yutaka Kobayakawa- Our typical weak yet cheerful character. Her role is to be the innocent one and sometimes be in a running gag in the 2nd half where she is in a relationship with Minami, one of her classmates. Though I think of her as a 2nd Tsukasa because she sometimes play the Moe role but of course Tsukasa take the top, sorry Yu-chan.


Minami Iwasaki- Our silent yet lovable character. I can't say much about her besides the her overused running gag of "flat-chest" which is a hit and miss because I'm guy, I can't understand that much.


Hiyori Tamura- Our stereotypical otaku girl who likes yaoi to yuri. She delivers some gags from here and there which is cool to me.


Patricia Martin- Our stereotypical stereotype foreigner because she could not be more stereotype about Japanese. She basically learned Japanese from anime and manga which I'm pretty sure that the author thought about us otakus outside from Japan. 


Then we have our 1st cast or our original favorite:


Miyuki Takara- Our favorite air-headed megane. i love her comedic scenes with her mother and the running gag in the dentist. Her running gags are comedy gold.


Konata Izumi- Our favorite and one of the best otaku girl we wish to exist. I love every scene with her which makes the scenes funnier.


Kagami Hiiragi- Our favorite tsundere character. I love her running gag about love and her tsundere tendency with Konata. Which bring one of my question " why are tsundere to Konata?"


Tsukasa Hiiragi- Our favorite clutz and moe girl. basically her role is the mascot girl. Sure she is not the best girl and the most comedic because Konata takes that spot but she is the cutest. She is my favorite girl and one of my WAIFU SO HANDS OFF. 


the others are just normal folks in everyday life.


Enjoyment: 7/10


This show is easily forgettable even though it is very comedic, art of the characters are MOE-tastic, and the opening is catchy. It is a show about nothing so don't expect that much but just pure laughs. It is just everyday life of normal high school girls that sometimes we do and we find it funny. Also later on the series where they show new characters, which are the new 4 rehash characters, is unnecessary because we already love the old ones and they don't feel new at all. Nonetheless, just as I said it is like a sitcom only poorly made but still could deliver fantastic humor. If only they make one story per episode then those 24 episode won't look like a random series of events.
