I'm one of the few who actually enjoyed this show. And I can understand why so many of you really dislike Lucky Star. It's simple-minded, a bit pointless, and has no heavy duty plot. But sometimes that's all you need. I don't typically watch these types of plot-less shows but sometimes I need a break from those epic, mind-blowing, fast paced dramas. Lucky Star has a way of providing just what I need when wanting to watch something simple, but also leaves me laughing out loud at all the little things. 
I believe that Lucky Star is actually a great representation of every day lifeof bored teenagers. The characters talk about things that shouldn't matter, always procrastinate, and get jealous of their friend's lovely curves. There are also a lot of references to other animes, and chances are, that if you don't watch a lot of anime, you will not get these references. Another reason I absolutely love this show is because it's kind of a parody of itself as well. If you watch the endings of each episode, when "Lucky Channel" comes on, you may or may not notice the little side remarks about what the characters do or say. I love this show and I think it's suited for anybody.


I don't think there is anything wrong with this anime, in fact, in may be one of my favorites. The fact that it is so simple makes me laugh a lot more. It's a show that you will be able to turn on, skip 3 episodes, and not need an explanation of what happened. The characters are also all hilarious in their own way and are very similar to a lot of people in real life. The scenarios are accurate to life, and things that every teenager goes through. I enjoy the fact that there are only four main characters, as opposed to several main characters. I'm not trying to beat up on animes that are sophisticated and have a lot of plots and characters, in fact, those are some of the best animes! I'm just saying that sometimes it's really nice to have a mellow show that is tailored for anyone and everyone. 


Overall 9/10

*SPOILER FREE REVIEW*
Some say it's a masterpiece, others describe it as gloriously bland. All I can say is that I had a lot of fun with this one.
Lucky Star. Where do we start? Story?
Haha, that was just a joke. Lucky Star hardly has a plot. It's just a showcase of a couple of girls' high-school lives.
While I suppose it can be linked to western sitcom as it focuses more on a general subject than any particular story arc, there's hardly even a clear goal that the characters try to achieve in most episodes.
Yet that factor ends up making this anime truly special.
This is a veryhonest and relatable show. It will make you laugh, on the very rare occasion it may even make you a little emotional.\n
But there is no action, no drama and no romance.\n
Even the comedy isn't that in-your-face most of the time.\n
Lucky Star's appeal comes from its appreciation of the mundane.\n
The joy often comes from feeling what the characters feel, it's sort of like an anime caricature of real life. …With added parody elements thrown in to spice it up.\n
When all is said and done though, it just works.\n\n
The art is fairly fluid and has a distinctive, borderline chibi art-style. It's nothing to be amazed by, but it does its job very well - Especially if cuteness is your thing.\n
Same applies to the OST and sound. Music isn't used very commonly, but when it is used it works within the context it's applied to. The theme song also gets bonus points for being stupidly catchy, even if its lyrics make no sense.\n\n
The characters are the driving force within the story. They will be the ones you will relate to, sympathise with and laugh at. And they do a pretty good job.\n
While some are more interesting than others, you will end up liking a fair amount. \n
They also pulled an awesome twist on the main character by making her an anime nerd.\n
So instead of making the main character a blank slate for the audience to fit themselves into, the main character IS the audience (or at least the most likely audience). \n
Even typical character archetypes like the tsundere or wolf in sheep's clothing are played exceptionally well. They fit in perfectly to the show's context, despite their simplicity.\n\n
It's safe to say I very much enjoyed Lucky Star, but I do have a few things to mention before you jump right into watching this.\n
Not everybody will like it. The pacing is slow. Very slow. If you're expecting loads of stuff to happen then you're watching the wrong show. The pacing instead adds to the effect.\n
I suggest watching this as a means to relax rather than pure entertainment, it's great to watch after having anything too intense in your day. It's like a stress-killer.\n
This also may not be the best show for complete newcomers due to sheer number of references and parody jokes made in it. Once you've watched just enough anime to get a general idea of the typical genres and clichés, then it'll probably make enough sense though.\n
Also I've only watched the sub so if the dub is bad, don't sue me. >w

Lucky star is a some what relaxing anime. It is highly addictive and  I couldn't stop watching it, I finished it in about 2-3 days. It is a slice of life comedy and totally random. There is near to no story line to this anime and every episode is very random.
Konata (main character) is a manga,anime,videogame (sim date rpgs) addict, a lot of the series is based on Konata and her trying to get all the manga she can :P.
Overall this is one of my favourite animes. It is my favourite Slice-Of-Life anime and joint first slice-of-life anime (joint with Minami-Ke)

Correct me if I am wrong, but I believe that Lucky Star is one of the pioneering anime of the 'four-moe-girls-doing-silly-chats' genre, a word that I've just invented myself. I've never seen an anime before Lucky Star's times that had the same style of humor and approach, but instead I noticed a lot of shows that seem to model after Lucky Star, such as K-ON, A Channel and Yuru Yuri.
STORY:
Anyway, if slice-of-life and random chatting isn't your cup of tea for an anime, then forget about Lucky Star. This anime doesn't have a main storyline at all, it just focuses on the lives of fourhigh school girls and the jokes they crack with each other. Ah, and if four isn't enough, you will meet with another four halfway through the series.


Your next question must be, "then what are the types of jokes that the girls crack?" Many, actually. I find puns the most frequent to show up, followed by random references to other anime series, especially The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya (which, appropriately, is another series directed by KyoAni, Lucky Star's studio). Besides that, there are also jokes that revolves around the Japanese culture, such as the food one in Episode 1.


Those who are not familiar with watching anime or the Japanese language/culture might have a hard time understanding most of the jokes in Lucky Star. Despite this, I would still recommend them to watch it. I was also like them when I first watched Lucky Star, and it was after watching the series many times that I can finally laugh heartily at the jokes.


From my narration above, you can probably guess two things. First of all, Lucky Star's jokes are truly funny when you are able to understand it. Secondly, even though you may not understand the jokes, you still would probably want to watch it again and again. Just for the slice-of-life moments that is depicted in the show. They are so simple, yet so wonderfully crafted. I still could not help but sometimes laugh at the thought of the many jokes played on Kagami (one of the main characters).


ART:

Absolutely loved it. Like the story, the art also took for a more simplistic style, but you never get bored of watching it. It blends with the slice-of-lifeness of the show well. The characters have great design too.


SOUND:

It's your normal comedy fare. Plain, unexciting tunes for the soundtrack that fit suitably into the "ordinary" nature of the show. The OP, "Mottoke Sailor Fuku" was great at the first impression, but gets a bit boring after a while. The EDs that change with every episode wasn't too memorable for me either.


However, Lucky Star's voice acting part was spectacular. Konata's seiyuu, Aya Hirano had a great vocal range as always, injecting life into every little segment of the character. Emiri Katou also had a wonderful voice that could not have been any more suitable for a tsundere role like Hiiragi Kagami.


CHARACTER:

Because it's a slice-of-life show that focuses more on developing the characters than the plot, you could naturally imagine how I felt about the characters of Lucky Star. I think it's quite self-explanatory already, so I'll skip this part for now.


OVERALL:

Yep, it's an anime that definitely deserves the praise it had received. It's also another great masterpiece in my collection that I would recommend it to my friends. By the way, I heard that KyoAni has done another similar anime called Nichijou this year, but I hasn't really seen it yet.

A typical 'slice of life' animes that has a main character that I can relate to way too much. its a fun and cute anime but the only problem is the lack of storyline. I mean I know that it was designed with no particular story added to it but it would have been nice to have the episodes a bit less random in terms of content.
but other then that its a good anime for people looking for complete randomness, I mean I still haven't worked out the meaning of the food conversation on the first episode but it still made me smile at howcompletely random it was XD

I recently watched this show for the second time after a few years and I must say, it's still just as funny.
The only 'poor' rating I gave was concerning the story. What can I say, Lucky Star doesn't HAVE a story but I won't condemn it for it. That's one of the aspects that make it so great.
The conversations are what really characterize this series. All you hear are every day conversations between some high school girls and the weird thing is, it's hilarious. I even found myself having some of those discussions with my friends. It was fun to tell them the facts Ilearned by watching this. X)\n\n
The animation fits the content perfectly. You shouldn't watch this expecting idealized high school girls. If anything they look younger.\n\n
The intro and outro are very typical as well. The intro is a bit catchy. The outro is simple but also made me laugh some times, it's too bad I didn't know most of the songs they sang. The end of this series actually gave me goose bumps.

I remember I started this anime back in my first year of high school, and after the first half of the series, I was all right with it. I enjoyed it. Other people call it boring, and I can definitely see why; then again, slice-of-life isn't for everyone. Back then I always enjoyed Lucky Star's constant references to anime and otaku tendencies because it was something that I could relate to and snicker at. I remember that I would play Lucky Star while folding the laundry or cleaning my room, kinda like how someone plays a podcast while doing busy work.
...However, that was a fewyears ago, and today I decided to finally finish up the rest of Lucky Star. One thing, I guess it looked better when I was younger. In my opinion, I think Lucky Star would have fared better as a 14 or 20 episode series because by the 17th episode, I was getting bored with the tiny bits of situational humor. I loved it when the story threw in a few personal bits of the characters' lives and feelings (I won't cite any because spoilers), and really, I wish that there was more of that towards the end of the series.\n\n
It's still a series that I would turn to when I need something to listen to while I do chores, but it isn't something that I would sit down for a watch. If you like cute girls constantly talking about nothing but daily life humor, then this is a good anime for you. I just wished this show could have taken a more personal approach like they did in a few bits of a few episodes.

Hooked from start to finish, the characters drew me in the most with this anime. The Soundtrack - very catchy. The theme song gets stuck in your head after listening to it once, and it the 18+ episodes where Shiraishi sings the ending themes and It cracks me up to the days. The art is very cuddly, not crisp and defined like most animes but that doesn't stop it from having a great persona. The Story is minimal, but that's what makes it so great, It's very laid back. Very much enjoyable from my perspective. 
Overall 10/10

Lucky Star is one of those odd shows that build its popularity and success off of directly parodying famous concepts of anime, games and manga.
Yet at the same time, it functions as more than just a parody, and serves as a story about four girls who are going through high school.
This is definitely a fan pleaser, with moe art and cute stuff, and lots and lots of references to famous anime like Code Geass, Higurashi and Kanon. 
While it serves its purpose, some of the comedy drags or is too reliant on the parodies. I haven't seen half these anime they talk about, so itwent right over my head. The ones I did know, I enjoyed. \n\n
The worst thing about the show was Lucky Channel, in which the humour was forced and very annoying, especially since one of the characters isn't even a character--he's just an animated voice actor rambling lines. It isn't funny. \n\n
But that doesn't stop the rest of the series. Not the best comedy, but a good one.

Aho luckyyyyyy!!!
Who said it's boring?
I know that there's no main plot and every episode has its own short stories and discussions about normal routine in Japan, but each character is very interesting and discovering their personalities, lifestyles, behaviours and biographies through all episodes is very, very interesting - including untypical elements like: endings (karaoke or Shiraishi's songs), Lucky Channel (short and funny programme with Shiraishi and Akira telling about each episode of LS).
And the most interesting for every otaku, nolife etc. who can identify themselves with her, main character - Konata, who plays MMOs and console games, reads manga, watches anime and many, many more.
Watchand don't even regret!\n\n
Bye-bee!

Lucky Star is one of those anime that is hard to talk about. In a way, the cutesy 'nya' faced Konata has almost become the face of anime as a whole nowadays so its no understatement to say that the show had a massive impact on the anime scene as a whole. But the show Di Gi Charat and the character Digiko had a similar role in the anime scene as well; it doesn't make either show genuinely good in any way. What makes shows like Di Gi Charat and Lucky Star reach these heights is not quality but rather the act of pandering. Injokes, if you will. From Project A-ko, to Di Gi Charat, to Lucky Star, this is an established tradition of anime--every generation of anime has that one show of in jokes about anime that immediately draws in the hits and legendary statuses because the viewer can go "Ha, I got that reference!". 


But like I said. None of this makes Lucky Star good. 


The story is pretty much not there. That's to be expected, since its a slice-of-life comedy, and there's no actual goal to be reached. It's more meant to be a skit show. But when your story is meant to be skit comedy then it has to be actually funny, and sadly I can't really say that about this show. When your very first skit is about the right way to eat a pastry with no self-awareness of the stupidity of the question, then there's a problem. The 'plot' (which is the jokes) begins to plod forward and ten minutes can feel like an hour. These slice-of-life skits are mixed in between Konata making references to Kadokawa and Bandai productions, because she's an lol nerd gurl, you know. Pick your poison: the plodding slice of life skits where nothing happens because the girls are too dumb to figure out basic logic, or the anime skits that just make you wish you were watching the anime in question instead of this trite watered down equivalent of Hot Topic shirts with a Keep Calm and Fandom On joke on them. 


A bad show can still keep me interested with good characters, and boy does Lucky Star trip over its own feet on that. We have Le Smug Anime Girl, the Hothead Busybody, the Klutzy Moe, and the Princess (or Ojou if you will). And trust me, they ain't going ANYWHERE outside of that. Oh and they all love video games and like to sleep a lot. Aren't they so RELATEABLE, guys? The rest of the cast is just a bunch of similarly one note personality anime tropes, and I suppose that's supposed to be the joke, but its not really all that funny. But I'll give the show credit, it DOES have characters that actually made me turn my head. Meito Anizawa is always funny in his ridiculous overacting and overanimation, and Akira and Shiraishi(the latter voiced by and based on the voice actor of the same name) never fail to make me laugh in their 'Lucky Channel' ending segments. I'd honestly rather watch a Lucky Channel show as opposed to 'Forced Reference Moeskits: The Show'. I ended up finding myself waiting desperately for the show to end so they could just get to the actual funny skit that was Lucky Channel. 


But I do have to give this show credit where credit is due. The animation is very good. It's fairly fluid, the designs are nice, and its got a bright and colorful look that fits the narrative of the show. It's not too saturated or desaturated in its coloring choices so it ends up looking nice, although we do have a fair share of pinks and purples. The voices, while ANNOYING, at least fit the characters. And I would be lying if Your New Favorite Earworm that is the Lucky Star opening isn't catchy. It is, and it caught on for a reason. The song is cute and fun but wacky and silly, and the dancing is of course addictive and fun. 


Sadly that's pretty much the only good things I have to say about Lucky Star. It looks pretty nice, and the sound is fitting with one hell of an earworm opening. Outside of that? I can't positively recommend this show to anyone. Not in good faith. It's a patently bad show made to cash in on otakus and in-jokes. There's nothing to it but that, and while a show can be good with in-jokes, this one simply is not. If you want a show with good in-jokes, try FLCL or Project A-ko. In the end you'll probably get more from those than you'll ever get from Lucky Star.

This show is definitely geared toward anime fans/Otakus. If you're brand new to anime I don't think you'll enjoy it quite as much. It requires some knowledge of anime/manga, and otaku culture to understand a lot of the jokes. But if you're a fan of anime I suggest you give it a watch. It can be quite funny. And don't let the cover fool you. I thought since the cast was all little girls (which they're not really little, they're supposed to be 17 to 18 years old) that it would be all cutesy moe stuff, but it's not (well mostly not). In fact thewhole moe thing is a source of a lot of jokes. One of the things I like about it is that it's pure comedy.  It's kind of like the "Seinfeld" of anime i.e. a show about nothing. It's just about funny everyday things, especially everyday otaku things. It's one of the few anime that I've found I can just sit down and laugh and nothing else. I would definitely suggest people give it a shot.

On top of just being one of the most fun slice-of-life comedy shows out there due to great comedy, memorable characters and a gorgeous presentation, what makes Lucky Star even more interesting is just how unique it is in the way it approaches everything - especially in its attitude, the way in which it chooses to flesh out its characters and how it showcases all of this in its presentation.
In regards to its attitude, structure and just how it feels, Lucky Star is simply like no other series out there. There's a general vibe of the show that's like it doesn't even know it's ananime or at least doesn't care to be anything like one (the meta Lucky Channel end segments and all of the ED's for episodes 13-24 being probably the biggest examples of this). Likewise, it doesn't even feel like any other comedy TV show, so much as it feels just like a day in the life of a bunch of Japanese high school girls in the year 2007, whose lives and friend interactions just happen to be rather comedic. This quality of the show is a result of its two most notable and controversial elements: one being that almost all of the runtime is dedicated to the characters just sitting around having small talk and discussing everyday things, and the other being that it contains an incredible amount of references to Japanese culture, otaku culture, anime, video games, etc. that were relevant at that time. This series is actually quite infamous and divisive for these reasons, with many expressing that they find it boring and/or that its reference humor is outdated and doesn't hold up anymore, but I have to at least partly disagree for a few reasons.


For one thing, despite most of the series just being characters talking about random everyday bullshit, I still do find it surprisingly entertaining - not only because I found the conversations to be pretty funny on their own, but also because of the characters that are having them and the way in which the conversations are presented (more on both of these things later). Secondly, most of the comedy in the show doesn't even come from reference humor, but rather from relatable situations and verbal abuse between friends. Lastly, although I'm sure most of them did fly over my head, the references in a way make this show like a time capsule for the mid-2000's, and as someone who loves history and especially history of pop culture, I really appreciate that. Also, its obvious references that the average viewer is more likely to get mostly still hold up really well today anyways. (Haruhi is still great, guys!)


However, as hinted at earlier, arguably the biggest reason why this series succeeds as much as it does is its cast - the characters in Lucky Star are fantastic and they completely sell the show's tone and comedy. All of them are so good-natured and have such entertaining personalities, that watching them do anything is a fun time. They're all incredibly relatable and fleshed-out, and much of the personal connection I had with this show stems from this. One of the biggest things I took away from watching this series was how I see a bit of myself in all of the main characters (particularly Konata and Kagami). The fact that this show manages to flesh out its characters as much as it does entirely through 24 episodes of everyday meaningless conversation is nothing short of utterly remarkable. After all, conversations are just as much about the people having them as they are about their subject matter, and Lucky Star is the first show I've ever seen to apply this logic to such an extreme degree. As opposed to other series, these characters aren't defined by their actions, development or backstory but rather by how they eat chocolate cornets.


As for the presentation that I was heaping praise on earlier, this is where this series stands out even moreso than it did already. Lucky Star is without a doubt not only the most pleasant-looking slice-of-life show I’ve ever seen but also one of the most aesthetically gorgeous shows of any genre I've ever seen, and this might just be its greatest strength. The art style, particularly in its character designs, steers away from the realistic look of later KyoAni shows like K-On! and goes completely over the top with being exuberantly bright, vibrant and girlishly colorful (purple, pink and blue dominate the color palette), and looks all the better for it. All of the cast’s designs are adorable and gorgeous to look at, being simplistic enough to look like anyone could draw them while still somehow remaining incredibly distinct and memorable. Like in Clannad, another KyoAni show that came out later the same year, the backgrounds are usually soft and made to contrast well with the characters’ more vibrant designs. Besides the art style, KyoAni also did an amazing job in making sure that a show which is mostly just filled with characters sitting around talking, still features some amazing animation and directing that help make all of its scenes visually engaging on some level. All of these elements of its presentation come together to give the show a soothing atmosphere and combined with the nonstop mostly inconsequential, fun dialogue, make this show incredibly enjoyable, pleasant and comfy to watch.


Now that I’ve touched on the good-natured characters and carefree tone of Lucky Star, that leads me into my next point, which is the lack of any real substantial drama or melodrama in the series. Depending on who you are and what you're looking for with this show, that will either be a disappointment or a blessing. I know I like comedies to have some emotional weight and heart to them, and can't really say this show maybe wouldn't have been even better with those elements in it, but we'll never know. Not to say there isn't some very rare moments of heartstring-pulling, but 99% of the show is played for laughs. I'm a bit torn on this myself but I guess, if nothing else, I have to at least respect the consistency in what this series was going for.


And on a final note, this series ended perfectly. Upon reaching the final stretch of episodes, there was an inescapable feeling that built up inside me, both of excitement to see how such a unique, lighthearted, carefree show like this would handle finality and also one of dread at realizing that my time with these characters was coming to an end. Without giving anything away, this show might not have a big, emotional graduation scene or anything of the sort for its finale (à la Angel Beats or K-On), but as mentioned before, Lucky Star isn't that kind of show. Instead, the final episode struck a chord of both pure, in-the-moment joy and sentimentality, perfectly capturing how these characters are living life to the fullest with their best friends at the end of what may be the best years of their lives, and it was everything I ever could have wished for.


I can’t say for certain if this show will continue to be a favorite of mine over time or exactly how much I’ll value the hours of conversation that I sat as an observer to, but I do know I’m going to value just how much damn fun it all was. This show is an utter fucking blast.

The first thing you should realize when deciding to watch this anime is that first and foremost it's in the slice of life genre. There'll be no dramatic plot or story, this is a show for you to watch when you want to relax or feel at peace (and at the end of the day, isn't that what anyone would want?) Second, the comedy will probably be a hit-or-miss for most people. Personally I found myself chuckling or smiling quite a bit. The characters are relate-able, the art is solid, there's honestly not many bad things I could say about the show. The only issueI can think of is one that most slice of life's face and that's the show can sometimes become too melancholic after a while; after all it's made to help you relax.\n
Overall, it's definitely a good watch that I'd recommend for anyone looking to unwind after a long day.

If you love cutesy anime and you're looking for something to watch just for the fun of it, this is a great choice.
There's not much story progress, but it's entertaining, good funny parts and it flows well. You look at this anime and think it's just for kids or younger people, but there's very mature humour mixed in basically everywhere, which is one of it's charms and gives you some pretty funny moments. 
I'm sure most of us here can relate with Konata in some way. The design of the girls is adorable. Their different personalities are a good mix and if you're someone wholikes watching a couple of episodes here and there it'll work well for you too. \n\n
At the ending of the episodes there's a little segment called Lucky Channel. Seriously, these parts are just as good as the episodes. Akira's annoyed side is very entertaining and full of crude humour.\n\n
If you enjoy Slice of Life, you'll most likely enjoy this. If you don't and you're still curious, give it a chance, but it probably won't entertain you very much. Also if you don't like high pitched/kiddy voices, probably not the best for you.

Lucky☆Star is a parody off of the stereotypical slice-of-life anime series. Numerous jokes and gags are spoofs of pre-existing shows crossing over multiple genres (Sailor Moon, Dragon Ball Z, Initial D, etc.) including itself as well. It should be noted that its targeted audience is towards avid anime fans who also enjoy watching slice-of-life comedies. By design, many potentially can be put off by the type of content that is incorporated in each episode. 
For those expecting a show focused around the relationships of four ordinary school girls, prepare to be disappointed. Konata, Kagami, Tsukasa, and Miyuki are not normal, though some may be relativelymore normal than another. The characters are made to be off kilter, far from degenerates, but candidly, "weird" in their own ways. The chemistry between the four of them can be very entertaining. 


The meta content is in of itself the story. Slice-of-life anime often do not have a meaningful plot, as it is a series of events. The students arrive at school, go to class, may engage in some activities and leave for home until graduation. Lucky☆Star almost embraces this fact too quickly to the point where there seems to be no direction at all. Conversation topics may seem random or even inane at times but that doesn't necessarily detract from the quality as long as you understand this is the joke. Ultimately, things happen and sometimes they don't. (Life is like that, no?)


Regardless, as part of the target audience, I did like the hypermeta content and fourth wall type allusions. Though, it's difficult to appreciate all of the gags in the show, I was able to catch most of them. Perhaps I am in the minority when I say I enjoyed the show. I believe the overall and intentionally misleading design catches people off guard, making it a rather polarizing series to begin with.

PREFACE:
Lucky Star is stupid. Lucky Star is like, REALLY, REALLY stupid. But I love it. The genre of "Funny slice of life anime" could be called over-saturated by some, and a dead horse so far gone it's just dust now by others. But in the genre, Lucky Star is one of the few incredibly standout series that can manage to make you smile no matter what mood you're in. The only real way to describe the series is "Dumb, silly fun." Or "otaku bait" but who cares? 
PLOT/CHARACTERS: It has no real overarching plot to it, it's just about 4 (and then 10) girls goingthrough high school. They each have their own traits and stuff, and they could be seen as one-sided, but who care's it's goddamn Lucky Star. You aren't watching this for gripping narrative or stellar character drama, you're watching it because you want to see a bunch of cute girls do silly things for 24 episodes. 


ART:

Lucky Star is adorable. Like, it's really cute. The moe-looking art style really lends itself to silly comedy anime, and it fits Lucky Star like a glove. Each main character is distinct and you can tell them apart from a glance.


SOUND:

Lucky Star has one of the most memorable OST's i've listened to in a slice of life anime this side of The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya. Punctuated with memorable and jolly piano tunes, as well as normal background music fare, it serves its purpose flawlessly, and I still hear the tunes in the back of my head as I go through my day-to-day life.


ENJOYMENT:

This is a personal aside, but I really love this series. My rating is a personal bias, sure, but I can't think of too many series that can make me smile no matter what mood I'm in. 


OVERALL:

Go watch it if you haven't. If you don't like it you'll just be biased and be reading this to laugh at, in your mind idiots, and if you like the series as much as me you're just looking for confirmation bias. I dunno man, go form your own opinion, but I really like it. Also, yes episode 1 sucks, we all know.

One of my favorite anime series.  I've watched both the Japanese subtitled version and the English dub several times and the voice acting in both is awesome.  Funny humor, interesting conversation, unique and awesome animation, and hilarious characters.

Okay at first I thought a review of this show would not be necessary mostly because there were already so many good reviews out there for it. But after watching the series for myself I have my own little opinions to say and make about Lucky Star.
Story- Okay yeah generic story line 4 please I've seen it a million times it won't be the first time I see it and it definitely won't be the last.
Art- Okay I like the art style it was interesting because it caused what I like to refer to as a cuteness overdose with in my brain which almost mademe loose my mind.\n
Sound- I loved the sounds the voice actors in the japanese version were good and if you watch the entrance song too many times it gets stuck in your head which is good.\n
Characters- Okay need to suffice to say garden variety appears a lot in  my head you see these same kinds of characters in almost every anime.\n
Enjoyment- In the end I kind of enjoyed it I mean it was funny sometimes and even had some originality but in the end the genericness of the characters and story took away from my enjoyment.\n
Overall- I thought it was good I suggest you watch and come up with your opinion as I think this is most likely a love it or hate it kind of anime.

Lucky Star is an anime that has years worth of reputation behind it, and while it eventually comes close to living up to that reputation, it doesn't do it soon enough to be an overall enjoyable experience. 
The cornet scene in the first episode is the worst that Lucky Star gets. Thankfully, the series only goes uphill from there. While I don't think the show as whole really gets good until the second cour, it never gets as unbearable as listening to them talk about the top end of a pastry for 10 minutes. Even the non-cornet scenes in episode 1 were better than thecornet scene. 


Rather than relying on the standard comedy fare of loud overreactions, the humor in Lucky Star is made up of references to anime, otaku in-jokes, and various aspects of everyday life. It relies on the viewer being in on the joke to be funny, so it's extremely hit-or-miss as to whether it works or not. The pacing of it all is really slapdash, with most scenes obviously being made up of random 4koma strung together. It makes the series feel like even more of an incoherent mess of random events than it already is. Fortunately, it improves a great deal after 12 or so episodes, and scenes start flowing closer to actual narratives. Though that could just be from an increase in anime original content, which is leaps and bounds better than when the show is adapting the manga. 


The characters in Lucky Star act closer to real life people than most other SoL comedies, which makes them more relatable. It almost feels like it's a commentary on how characters in other “slice of life” comedies act nothing like how a normal person would. However, I feel that because of this,  the series keeps itself from becoming as entertaining as it should be. Nobody acts quirky enough for what they do or say to be funny. They talk about boring things in boring ways and it's sleep inducing. It persists until episode 13 when the secondary cast gets introduced and the series starts feeling like it has some life to it.


The show is well animated from beginning to end, even if most of it is wasted on still frames of talking heads. Everything stays on model and moves fluidly, as expected of KyoAni. However, the art style has never sat right with me. It’s too chibified for me to buy that Lucky Star is supposed to a slow and relaxed SoL. It looks like it’s supposed to be fast paced gag comedy, which just clashes with all the scenes of slow paced conversations. The most energetic part of the show is the OP, which makes Lucky Star look way more entertaining than it actually it. It's counter-intuitive to what the show is trying to be.


I think Lucky Star's main problem, aside from just being boring, is just that it's aged horribly since 2007. There weren't as many comedy anime with all girl casts and slice of life settings back then. Azumanga Daioh, Ichigo Marshmallow, and Hidamari Sketch are the only real major ones that come to mind. Now, there's plenty of cute girl comedies out there which do the exact same things that Lucky Star does, while also having more coherent narratives and exciting characters to back it up. I think that Lucky Star would have aged far better if it were more like Azumanga instead. I get that Lucky Star wanted to be clever by being aware of SoL cliches, but being more cliched would be preferable to just being nothing.


Lucky Star does a lot of things right and that’s the most disappointing thing about it. It could have been a really great show overall, but it spent half of its run-time stumbling in quality. It’s an easily relatable show, so I can see why so many people like it. If there's anything that Lucky Star does better than other shows, it's being a slice of life that doesn't try embellishing it with extra details. It's probably not deserving of being considered one of the most well known SoL comedies out there, but it got good enough that I could be disappointed in the bad parts. Which is more than can be said for most shows out there.

BEFORE you start watching this anime, you have to watch The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya because this anime makes a lot of references to that anime and you'll just enjoy Lucky Star a lot more if you've seen Haruhi.
First, I understand that Slice of Life animes like to focus more on the characters then the actual story of the anime, but what genre would an anime that doesn't focus on anything fall into? 
That's what bothered me most about this anime was its lack of focus, it was almost like the writers had ADD. One moment we're listening to how Miyuki hates going to thedentist, but out of nowhere we jump to Konata playing video games at home with no transition. Every episode is like that! Every episode is just these unconnected funny moments! I got a headache from watching this anime; one second it's morning and the girls are going to school, but then the anime jumps to them leaving school in the afternoon!? 


However, even though there is no story of any kind, I did like the characters. I love Konata because she's an otaku and is always confusing people with these anime references she makes. Also, her dad is so weird (i.e. I think he has a schoolgirl fetish), but that's what makes him so interesting. Plus, Konata's cousin, Yui, is a cop, but she's so irresponsible. 


So, it isn't like I flat out hate the characters, but the problem is they're very static. Part of the enjoyment of reading a book/manga or watching a movie/anime is seeing how the characters change and overcome problems. But this anime has no problems and the characters never grow closer or learn a lesson, there's no character development of any kind. 


Overall: I'd recommend this anime to people just because I think its so unique (in that it's the only anime I've about nothing) that I'd want people to experience it and see how they feel about it.

~Story~ 6/10
Lucky Star is a series that has a loose storyline, but does not deviate from the big picture. After viewing a few episodes, it follows more like that of Azumanga Daioh and Ichigo Mashimaro. This is a slice of life story that is realistic, and is full of skits all around. Some viewers may scrunch their eyebrows at the questions the main characters ask, and the discussions that follow, and there are some punchlines that may be dubious to comprehend, but it does not affect the story overall. The story plot, which is weak, is strengthened with the
characters, who reflect different personalities and persuasions.It's a good balance.


~Art~ 9/10

The motions of the characters are fluid, and it just feels like the animation is clean from the get go. The details might need to be a bit more improvement, but it's not as much an issue because it holds its own. Some of the scenes, like Tsukasa in the ocean during the beach vacation, or Kagami's tears after confessing to Konata about her weight gain, are indeed detailed, and are done tastefully well. The OP of the show even has some computer animations, too. The art, the direction, and the way Kyoto Animation did this series reflects their work of The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya, and its formula can be adjusted for any series that they work on. The art matches the emotions, the storylines, and the thoughts. Altogether, in spite of a need for a little more detail, it is another solid KyoAni effort. If I could give it an 8.5, I would, but a 9 should be close enough.


~Sound~ 6/10

Lucky Star has a rather nifty way of promoting silliness and ingenuity in one using their opening theme. "Motteke! Sailor Fuku" is a very upbeat and catchy song reminiscent of Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya's ending song "Hare hare Yukai " in which it also sports a wacky dance number. On the Other hand, the long list of ending songs is just too much and the only recurring theme is they are being played while the characters are singing in a karaoke bar!


~Character~ 6/10

Konata Izumi, the main protagonist, has a fetish for chocolate cornets, as well as a number of anime and

manga shows that are also popular. Not surprisingly, she is an avid follower of Haruhi Suzumiya (the seiyuu

of both characters is Aya Hirano), and you also have plenty of other anime and manga references. And in

spite all her bubblyness, and the catlike smile she loves to sport, she has skeletons in the closet, too: her

mother died when she was young. She is a "Jill of all trades," the renaissance girl, and the otaku, all in one.

Kagami Hiiragi is the tsundere-type of girl in this series, and a popular girl in her class. Aesthetically, she is an

interesting person to pay attention to, more so than her sister Tsukasa, although there are attributes that make her unique. Miyuki Takara is your meganekko in the show, and after Konata talks with her about what her weaknesses are, she sees her in the moekko mold. The supporting characters have their unique quirks: Yui

Narumi, Konata's cousin, and her teacher, Nanako Kuroi, are akin to Yukari Tanizaki and Minamo Kurosawa

in AzuDai. Akira Kogami and Minoru Shiraishi, who both host the Lucky-Channel portion of the show, are a

boke-tsukkomi duo.

Some other well known characters outside of Lucky Star even cameo in the series, like Sergeant Frog. I feel

it may take away from the story, but these guest stars add another dimension to this sitcom of a series. Lucky

Star can also be thought of as a sitcom in a way, a situational comedy with punchlines at every twist and

turn.


~Enjoyment~ 8/10

This show make me smile, laugh, and bored. If you like SOL genre, I  recommend you to watch this.

Well, it's pretty enjoyable. Some of the jokes can be funny, some just will make you giggle a bit. And remember, it's a Slice of Life, so it has no plot. It's the main problem with Lucky Star. It'll be boring to most viewers.
I can sympathize with some of the characters. Like Konata. She's an otaku and loves so stay in the computer, Like me. The characters are worth liking. Miyuki is the typical clumsy and air-headed moe girl. Tsukasa is also a moe, and has her twin sister Kagami, who is the typical hard-working, easily angered Tsundere.
Overall, this anime is good, but it's ashow about nothing.

Wow, the review section really is split in two here! So just a heads up, this show isn't for everyone!
But if (like me), you can appreciate the Slice of Life genre, then this anime should prove as good choice, as it's likely the most SoL dedicated show i've seen yet.
So, what's inside this 24 episode bundle? well a few aspects that make up this show include the comedy throughout, as it's a light hearted anime after all: and the art style compliments this greatly, it gives a cartoon-like vibe, and it should click with you especially if you like your colours vibrant!
The show is orientedabout the daily lives of high school girls, and so it's not a surprise that the story in terms of a plot is lacking, but as i said earlier, the "story" part of a SoL anime like this one is mostly conveyed through the characters. So this is where the divide occurs, do you think it's entertaining? or do you think it's pointless? \n\n
Diving into the character aspect, i came to appreciate a good variety of personalities in Lucky Star, from the quirkiness of Konata, to the diligence of Kagami - and many more.  During the show, you come to find out more about the predominately female cast.\n\n
The presentation throughout is effective, this referring to the combination of the emotive art, and the very casual dialogue. So If your looking for a break from the vast array of action shows out there, this one is a good bet - as all signs point to this show as being designed to entertain. - and that really is all there is to it. Yet  it all depends on your definition of "entertaining".\n\n
For me, this anime was a pleasure to watch, and as long as the cuteness and slightly cliche'd aspects don't throw you off, i'm sure you'll agree. \n
Don't you worry, because i'm coming to a  close now, but if you are to take\n
anything from this review: relax, forget your troubles, you are now in the right mind set to watch Lucky Star :)

Lucky Star is one of those animes that if you don't get the subtle references/jokes in the anime, you pretty much will find it meaningless to watch. It's best part is that in every episode, references are crammed into every episode, and every reference has made me laugh. Its one of those animes that I recommend that IF YOU CAN'T FIND AT LEAST 5 REFERENCES (from other anime, games, lifestyle jokes), DON'T WATCH IT. For people that can catch way more than that (like me), you will enjoy tremendously.

I love this anime the characters are adorable and its really funny I had so much fun watching it and even in the end its funny, I honestly think everybody should watch this anime its the best you have every single kind of character in it polite, smart, annoying, dumb, crazy, creepy. Its ALL in there and I'm positive you will enjoy this anime especially if you like food like I do! ✿

Lucky*Star is one of the most interesting anime out there, if one of the hardest to understand by outsiders.
Again, much like Azumanga Daioh, the execution of a normally dull slice of life storyline is great and has a lot of charm and humor. One of the things that made me love Lucky Star so much was the conversations the characters had. They were completely normal conversations that I find myself discussing almost exactly the same subjects with my otaku friends.
The characters are full of personality, especially our anime addicted heroine with the blue hair, Konata Izumi. Arguably one of the most interesting anime girls outthere, Konata says what all of us otakus have on our mind and even more.\n\n
Overall, sadly, I can only recommend Lucky Star to Otakus. Fans of the Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya will especially love the constant references to the Haruhi series within Lucky Star. However, new comers to anime should leave this anime for later, as Lucky Star's humor mainly derives from the Anime/Manga/Japanese Videogame/Moe/Visual Novel subculture and those not versed in their ways will see jokes pass right over their head.

Lucky Star at the time of me watching it was the one I had heard the most about. The people in my university’s anime club mentioned it all the time whenever we played anime-related games. My online friends have also told me about it as well as a couple of my classmates. After getting really bored one day I decided to blitz through the series. I now understand why everyone has seen this anime: It has to be the biggest love letter to anime fans ever! Cute girls, an otaku main character, and anime and video game references.  Here are my thoughts on it:
Story:
Sincethis is a slice of life and school anime, there is no real story. It’s just 4 girls going through daily high school life.


Art: 

The colours in this anime are almost blinding. There’s so much colour in this anime. There’s a lot of diversity just in the characters’ hair colour. I think all the main colours are represented! Despite all the colour, it doesn’t distract from the overall look. As for the characters themselves, they’re drawn in quite nicely.  


Art – 10


Sound:

Normally I mention music in the sound department but there isn’t a lot of music to speak of in this anime. Music is only used at certain points. For example, whenever Konata is explaining her way of thinking or when she’s making a joke, whenever Miyuki explains something to the group, or during certain events. Other than that, it’s up to the voice actors to keep the sound quality up. All the voice actors, English and Japanese, did a good job with their characters although I preferred the English Tsukasa to the Japanese one and the Japanese Miyuki to the English one. Both Konata’s and Kagami’s voice actresses did great work and their performance was the same to me. A few people have complained about Patricia’s English voice actor but people have to remember that because this anime takes place in Japan and she’s from the US (in the show), they have to make her sound weird when she speaks to pretend like she has an accent. I’m not a fan of her voice either but there’s an explanation for you.

The opening theme of the anime: “Motteke! Sailor Fuku!” is one hell of an addicting song. Just give it three episodes and you’ll be hooked on it. At first I just thought it was plain weird but after a while the song just gets stuck in your head and refuses to let go. The ending song is always different but they’re all references to one anime or another.


Sound - 8


Character:

Even though I’ve only started watching anime this year, I know of most of the stereotypes there are in anime. I know each character usually represents a certain trait. From what I understand, Lucky Star’s group of 4 each represents an anime stereotype. You have the joker and otaku Konata, the hot-headed, straight man Kagami, the airhead Tsukasa, and the smart, formal, glasses-wearing Miyuki. That’s all right and all but it’s the way that the creators poke fun at these stereotypes is what makes it funny. Konata makes references to these stereotypes especially with Tsukasa and Miyuki who are the stereotypical ‘moe’ characters and Kagami who is ‘tsundere’. Konata is constantly making references to the three girls and since Kagami is the straight man and the tsundere, Konata makes fun of her the most. As such, the two make a great duo when it comes to this anime. Over the half way point in the anime, they introduce a whole new set of characters that joins the main cast but they don’t fit in all that well. I would have preferred it if they just kept the original cast in there for the duration.


Character - 9


Enjoyment:

For most people this will be the part that fluctuates the most. The more you know about anime and the more series you know, the more you will enjoy this anime. It also helps if you have knowledge about video games, particularly visual novels/eroges and JRPGs. They make references to so many things, it’s almost impossible to get every reference unless you’re a real otaku. But if you want a faster  way to understand most of the references, watch all of Kyoto Animation’s stuff that they made prior to Lucky Star (Full Metal Panic: Fumoffu, Air, Kanon). But if you only wanted to watch one series before Lucky Star, make sure it’s The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya (Suzumiya Haruhi no Yuuutsu). Almost half the references they make in the series come from The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya with at least one reference per episode or two in the next tom make up for one they missed. There’s one episode that devotes almost half its time to the series. I cannot stress it enough: watch The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya before Lucky Star! I made the mistake of watching Lucky Star first; don’t make the same mistake I did! 

But anyway, I really enjoyed Lucky Star even the first time around and it gets funnier every time I come back to it since I’ve watched some other series and now I can get another reference they make. Parodies in general are a love/hate thing for people but I loved this one.


Enjoyment - 10


Overall:

If you fancy yourself an anime expert, looking for something funny to watch, or just looking to relax, Lucky Star will suit your needs. I wouldn’t recommend watching this series too early in your anime career unless you already know a lot about anime and its stereotypes as well as its terms. If you don’t like parodies or moe-centric anime then steer clear but otherwise, sit back and have some fun!


+ Rewards you for being an otaku! :P

+ Fun to re-watch as you progress along your anime-watching career

+ Konata is awesome!


- requires anime knowledge beforehand


Overall – 9

Lucky star is definitely the most random and funniest animes out there! It links different animes into the show, it includes "Lucky Channel" at the end of each episode which is really funny and it is really entertaining! There's not much of a story so you'll never really know whats gonna happen in the next episode which I find really interesting. I really recommend this anime to all those that like funny animes.

Lucky Star is one an anime where you ether love it or hate it. I've met very few people who have cone to think of it as just "okay" or "good." If you can get past the fact that there is absolutely no story, then you might want to read on. If not, this is not your type of anime. 
PROS
The art in this anime is completely, absolutely, and 100% cute. Everything is colored very brightly, similar to Ouran High School Host Club, but much cuter (yes, I said it). It just has the feel of the ultimate teddy bear that you want to hugand keep holding on to. The characters themselves, look as bright as ever, especially Konata with her blue hair. It's drawn as cute as you can get (pretty much).


I consider Lucky Star to be the king of comedic anime. Every joke works and is spot on. Konata is involved with most of these jokes, but of course other characters add-on their own sense of humor a lot as well. It's hard to find an anime that has comedy even close to the high level of humor that is within Lucky Star.


The characters in Lucky Star are, as you would imagined, extremely cute. Of course, the majority of fans love Konata more than anyone else, but others have a lot to add as well. Konata is a young girl who loves anime, computer-gaming, and video games. She's basically the girl version of many guys who love her as much as they do. Kagami is kind of your average school girl who tries her best at stuff and is, for the most part, the victim of Konata's jokes. Tsukasa is the sister of Kagami and is the shy girl of the series. She plays her part the way any anime character can. Lastly, there is Miyuki - the smart girl. Judging by these descriptions, you would think that there is no character development throughout the series. Well, you are correct, but there doesn't need to be. This is a slice of life anime that is about everyday things in life. Character development is not needed for such. 


CONS


Many people seem to have a strong hatred for Lucky Star because they say it has no story. Others who love Lucky Star have said that it does. Facts are facts, though. And the fact is this - Lucky Star has no story. I don't care what you hear from other people or how much you are convinced that this anime does have a story. It doesn't. Now, this doesn't take away much if you are into slice-of-life anime. If you have a problem with such, then this anime will be your worst nightmare. 


At the end of every Lucky Star episode is a segment called "Lucky Channel." This segment involves two characters getting into weird and awkward fights. Honestly, the segment didn't bother me at first, but as I saw more and more episodes, it got quite annoying. Maybe it is just me, but I can't stand those parts.  


OVERALL


Lucky Star is one of the greatest anime series to ever hit television. It's hilarious in almost every single way and has some of the most likeable characters you will ever meet. The only downside is that there is no story, which may bother some viewers interested in such.

Lucky Star - Let's start off by saying that this isn't one of those shows that's well-rounded and just about every anime fan can love. Whether or not you like this show is very dependent on your anime prefrences. For example , if you need to have a very strong plot line in the show, and characters that develop over time. Don't watch this show. If you like funny , cute anime's that have really no point at all , this is the show for you. 
The humour- I won't deny it, this show is funny., very funny. The characters have great personalities and arevery relatable. This show is the show you turn to after just finishing up a series that's very intense with a very complicated plot line. 



The story- The story, to say it bluntly, is lacking. VERY lacking. in fact, there is no story really. The episode are rather pointless. It's essentially like a whole series of fillers. This makes it very hard for people (like me) to sit down and watch it till` you finish. (and im sure we've all done that before). After just a few episode you'll start to get bored. 


The characters- The characters personalities are great. They're very funny and the way the main characters interact gives for some good laughs. However, if you like to see characters develop any, you won't like this. The character's have NO development. at all.

I give this anime an 87/100
I discovered Lucky Star on it's first run in 2007, right when I became totally ambitious about anime like I am now. Back then, I became obsessed with anything I laid my eyes on, like this and Gundam 00. I even have all the DVDs for Lucky Star sitting in a shoe box in my basement. When I watched it, I loved it. But now that I think about it, I don't think it's the masterpiece that it really wants to be. But I still love it.
So basically it's about high school girls just doing things. I don't mind storiesabout kids just doing normal things (well, normal in a Japanese perspective. I'm from America and you don't see stuff like this in my country) just as long as they're either executed properly or don't turn into a blatant ecchi fest. Thankfully Lucky Star's the former, even if I do confess that some particular episodes were a tad boring.


The animation is...well, great. Not just great in terms of its use of color and just making characters move. It doesn't just make the main characters move around, but the people and objects in the background too! And it does this ON A REGULAR BASIS! That shows that KyoAni certainly has some kind of endless budget (along with A-1 Pictures and I think maybe even Madhouse when they want to) when it comes to animation. Sure, I like Kyoto Animation sometimes, but not because of Haruhi Suzumiya (don't like it. Never watched it and never will. Sorry!). The soundtrack...well, there isn't much music in the show. And when there is background music, it's kinda minimal. But I don't really mind.


And of course you can't have Lucky Star without a colorful cast of characters, not just because of appearance but personality as well. They're all perfectly diverse and different and relatable and THANKFULLY down to earth to a degree. My favorites have to be the Hiiragi twins, but for different reasons. Unfortunately, there are characters who either just confuse me or annoy me, and one of them happens to be Akira Kogami. I mean, what's the point of her being on the show? I don't get it. Plus her abuse of Minoru (WHY is the voice actor portraying an animated version of himself!? Was this in the original manga!?) really annoyed the heck out of me (and I was happy when he got back at her. Violently. Like a raging tiger).


By the way, you guys NEED to watch the English dub! It's GREAT! The English voices are all great! I especially love Yutaka's voice. She's voiced by Starfire from Teen Titans! And she can do little girl voices! Huzzah!


So long story short, Lucky Star's just your clone of Azumanga Daioh but with more anime and pop culture references than just slice of life comedy. I don't have that much to say about it, but even with it's flaws I still love it. And Kagami FTW! And not just because she's a tsundere and because she's voiced by Kari Wahlgren in the English dub!

I can honestly say that I enjoyed this anime much more than I enjoyed a lot of other anime that are comedy based and set in a high-schooler's world. Lucky Star managed to have the right balance of more serious moments, along with teasing and comic relief. It followed the girls on their journey through high school, anime, and working. 
As a computer nerd, I definitely related to Konata and her need to constantly binge watch TV shows and play computer games. This, coupled with the fact that they didn't make her character a typical, boy-crazy, sell-out with big boobs who just happened to likegeeky things, made me want to continue watching it. 


I thought it was adorable and fun, and a refresh from all of the popular action/supernatural anime that's popular right now. 


I would recommend it if you're looking for an anime that you can watch casually, without having to worry about completely misunderstanding the story line if you miss or decide to skip a few episodes, and if you want something funny and cute. 


(I also learned the dance routine from the last episode. It was absolutely adorable.)

Lucky Star is an anime about 4 female students and their lives. It's very relaxed and is a lot about school life.
Story - 7: This may just be me but i found the storyline very confusing. I don't understand very well what's going on half the time. But when I do, it's funny. The scenarios are very funny and there's plenty of humor. I wouldn't say that I laughed constantly, but I did snicker a few times per episode. Quite entertaining.
Art - 8: The art is very childish. It fits the fun and relaxed setting and tone.
Sound - 8: Good sound quality. Nothing special here.
Character- 10: Here's where I think the anime shines the most. The characters are very fun and lovable. All 4 girls are unique in their own way. I can easily say that people can connect with one of them. It was really fun to watch because of the characters. They really fun to watch.\n\n
Enjoyment - 8: I really enjoyed the anime. It was funny. The only thing I don't really like is the complexity of the story line. I may simply be misunderstanding in which there is no real story line but yeah.\n\n
Overall - 8: Great anime. I wouldn't say it's going to be a favorite. But I could suggest it to anybody who likes a good laugh and/or enjoys the school life animes. \n\n
Note: There's no ecchi or love in this anime. I know love is really becoming an aspect about animes today, but there's little to none in this. Doesn't take anything out of the anime though.\n\n
Please enjoy!

Many anime fans who complain this anime. I don’t know why that is obvious, they always assume the same arguments. Like “What the fuck, there’s no plot?” or “This fucking show has no pointless to show.” Those are the anime fans complaints about this anime. Actually, why? Do they not read the synopsis before you started watching or look at the genre, please? After all, this is a slice of life, not a fucking mainstream anime.
But what makes this anime so interesting? This anime is very relaxing to watch, ranging from conversations about food, hobbies, and so forth. The things discussed by this anime isvery striking for our daily lives. Like for example, making a voice in front of the fan to make it sound like a robot, Japanese culture, otaku daily life, and others.


Konata is an interesting otaku. Her father also has the same hobby for generations. Her own class teacher is also an Online Game Addict and an online friend. The story is also no less exciting with other anime. The character has a unique drawing made like a chibi. The Slice of Life and Comedy section are also very interesting, although this anime more focus on daily life so comedy is minimal. As I said earlier, this anime has no main story. So you are only seeing short stories with conversations that make you laugh. There is also cultural information and sometimes also incorporating other anime into the core of the story or arguably, Parody. For example Code Geass, The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya, Gundam, Vocaloid, and so on.


Sound, BGM, and Sound Effect are very nice to hear let alone relaxing time scene. The passionate of opening with strange but pleasant lyrics. The ending can be considered very strange and interesting. The first episode until the 14th, we will be prepared vocals from Konata and friends. Until episode 15 to the end, there is an appearance that either what might be a producer or a hilarious seiyuu. Before heading to the ending, there is also something interesting that is Lucky Channel, an additional show and a little information about Lucky Star. Sometimes their conversations are very strange.


Overall, for casual anime fans or slice of life maybe you can watch this anime. Not recommended for someone who just wants to find a plot or something. Although like that, this anime is also included in my favorite slice of life anime list.

To be fair, I began to ask myself if I was finally becoming what people call "otaku" with this show. The story doesn't really exist, it is still nice to watch, and you just can't not love these characters. Konata has a very cute voice, Kagami reminds me of Kyou from Clannad in a lot of ways (I watched Clannad just before this), and everything is just... cute. 
This is just some episodes of random cuteness with some jokes. It's pure, and I just liked it. 
As somebody who rates a show on "how much do I want to meet the characters", I can't thinkof it in any bad way even if there is no point, goal, nor anything obvious in this show that would be called "story"

At first glance, Lucky Star seemed to be just a group of cheerleaders just going through high school, but after finally deciding to actually watch the anime, my opinion changed completely.
You could say that Lucky Star has no plot whatsoever, but if there were to be one, it's just basically, "The Daily Life of Highschool Girls" That's literally all the anime is about.
But, it somehow managed to keep you fully entertained for the whole 24 episodes, not to mention that the humor is pretty on-point, especially when Konata and Kagami is involved.
This show isn't the funniest that I've seen, but sometimes, the humor could leaveyou gasping for breath.\n
For a lot of people, when they first start Lucky Star, they describe it to be...boring. I do agree with that statement, but a lot of people didn't even bother to watch the rest of the episodes after seeing episode 1. After episode 5, the episodes now show improvement, and become even more enjoyable than when it first started.\n
In my opinion, Lucky Star is one of the best slice of life anime out there, and actually inspired a lot of other slice of life series. Even if it still has its flaws, like every single anime that I have seen myself, it's definitely recommended.

Lucky Star is quite an outstanding and certainly entertaining slice of life comedy that shares high similarity to Azumanga Daioh - but with a lot more otaku culture thanks to its main character: Kona-chan (Konata Izumi).
Story-wise it's a slice of life anime but it does follow some loose trajectory, but each individual story is very enjoyable as it's characters are full of heart and their dynamics work great with each other.
I had a blast watching Lucky Star, it's especially a treat if you're into otaku culture and/or video games. Characters are relateable and have tonnes of heart. This anime is certainly a gem in itsgenre.\n\n

Lucky Star is one of those anime that looks kind of girly and not very funny.  However if you give it time, say two or three minutes, it will start to hit a funny bone or two.  Lucky Star does something that few anime have done and does it will.  It takes the anime fan and makes you take a look at how "the rest of the world" sees you.  Because of this I now have a cool little figure of one of the characters setting on my entertainment center that my family gave me.  It was given to meafter my parents were helping me clean up for a Christmas party and I was watching Lucky Star.  The figure has a note permanently attached to it with one of her famous lines that my mother thought was fitting for me.  It sets on top of a stack of anime and every time I go and get an anime to watch i see the figure and hear her voice saying that line.  Thank you Kari Wahlgren.  Thought the art is a little "cartoonish"  it is very well done and the story is very well thought out and presented in a very entertaining way.

I would say its for 12 years and up because its a tiny bit rude but its suitable for 12 year olds. But people younger than 12 can still watch it but they need to watch it whith an adult.
